title: chavez socialist experiment venezuela opinion
story: GDP growth will stall. Taxes will rise. We’ll even run out of Mars bars.But across the Atlantic, something has been ­happening that should give us all some perspective.Over the past decade, Venezuela has plunged into the abyss — but there’s been no civil war, no earthquakes or hurricanes.Just a brutal, corrupt government that has turned what was once Latin America’s richest country into a hellhole.Starvation rations plunged millions into hunger and ­malnutrition, with some resorting to eating dogs, cats, even zoo animals.People got into kne fights over the right to scavenge from a dumpster.Its economy is more than three times smaller than in . Inflation climbed into the thousands, then millions of per cent.The result has been a refugee crisis on the scale of the Syria conflict.No wonder tens of ­thousands of people took to the streets of the capital Caracas this week, declaring national assembly head Juan Guaido the legitimate president.All this is awful for the poor bloody Venezuelans.But what does it have to do with Britain The answer is that Venezuela wasn’t just a ­disaster. It was an experiment — cheered on by Jeremy Corbyn and his cronies.In , Hugo Chavez took over Venezuela.He ruled until his death in , when he was succeeded by his hand-picked protege Nicolas Maduro.Chavez modelled himself on Latin American ­revolutionaries like Fidel Castro and Simon Boli. He nationalised much of the oil industry — which dominates the ­Venezuelan economy — and imposed punitive taxes on foreign firms.He introduced price controls and later currency controls. He declared “economic war” on the “stateless ­bourgeoisie” and seized the goods of private companies he denounced as saboteurs.For Corbyn, the Chavez regime was an inspiration — a chance to see true socialism brought to le.Venezuela, Corbyn has said, “showed us that there is a dferent, and a better, way of doing things. It’s called socialism”.It wasn’t just Corbyn. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott and Corbyn’s media chief Seumas Milne have all praised the ­Venezuelan revolution.That “better way of doing things” has ruined tens of millions of lives but there has not been a hint of an apology from Corbyn.Normally, the fact that people are taking to the streets to free themselves of a vicious regime would be cheered to the rafters by the Left.Instead, there is the silence of those who find themselves ­hideously embarrassed.The few who are not ­staring at their shoes claim that Venezuela has been the ­victim of an American plot.That Maduro took, in McDonnell’s words, a “wrong turn” from Chavez’s true socialism.That it was all down to a falling oil price.Yes, Maduro took a wrong turn. But that turn was to follow the path laid out by Chavez.From the Soviet Union to Cuba to Venezuela, there is a long and shabby history of British left-wingers acclaiming a workers’ paradise — only to declare, once its ­failure is clear, that it wasn’t really socialist after all.Never mind the millions of lives ruined — let’s have another go!If he became Prime ­Minister, Corbyn might not succeed in turning Britain into Venezuela. But we’d be Caracas to let him try.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: remain wreckers should listen to queen
story: Her Majesty is right that MPs must find the common ground. But whatever compromises are made on the finer details, that “common ground” must at its core deliver on . million votes to leave the EU, and the promises made in both Tory and Labour manestos at the last election.Those trying to derail Brexit are the ones who are, as Her Majesty puts it, “losing sight of the bigger picture”. After all, it is they who are willing to rip up centuries of democratic understanding and procedure to keep us locked within the European Union.So terried of Britain flourishing, free from Brussels’ dead hand, that they will happily destroy public trust in Parliament in order to succeed.We wish they shared Her Majesty’s obvious confidence in her country.As MPsto their constituencies this weekend, they will hear the same thing over and over again: deliver what we voted for.Those still hoping to delay Article  or even for a second referendum MUST realise the stakes.MARCH th should be a momentous day, our first outside the European Union. And it should also be the day the Prime Minister fires her hapless Chancellor Philip Hammond.Free to set our own course again, we can create the world’s most competitive economy — with lower taxes and business-friendly regulation that allows our brightest companies to prosper here and across the world.Our Eeyore Chancellor is about as far away from the dynamism we need as it is possible to imagine. At a time when we need to put energy into the economy, Hammond is human chloroform.And that’s before we get on to his outrageous disloyalty in Davos this week.The clock is ticking.JUST as most serious European leaders are thinking of creative ways to stay close to the UK after we leave, Leo Varadkar and Emmanuel Macron show just how hopeless they both are.That France’s Macron — a Poundshop Napoleon without the self-doubt — dares to lecture us when he’s got riots on the streets and approval ratings to match his stature really is quite something.Meanwhile Ireland’s Leo, who never knowingly turns down the opportunity to insert his foot squarely into his mouth, threatened that he would send the Army to the border yesterday before being forced into a screeching U-turn.And they say we’re the problem…Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady influencers dont see kids friends cash
story: Weirdly, for those of us who grew up before the internet took off, that’s an actual job now.And who can blame people for ­saying: “‘Yes please” to money for doing not very much But there is something wrongInstagram users aren’t aware the ­celebrities they follow are being paid thousands of pounds — or even hundreds of thousands — to promote the products they are “recommending”.Advertisers know Instagram — which has a BILLION monthly users posting some million photos a day — is an incredibly powerful way of reaching young people.The more followers a star has, the greater their selling power.Kylie Jenner, who has million ­followers, is paid a whopping £, for every sponsored post.Under the  UK Consumer Protection From Unfair Trading regulations, ­celebrities paid to plug products are supposed to make that clear.But there are no simple guidelines.So while some celebs might say “sponsored” or “#ad” on a post, others are less open about it.That is why the Competition  ­Markets Authority conducted an ­investigation.And this week  British celebrities and “influencers” were found to have failed to follow consumer protection guidelines.They include singers Rita Ora and Ellie Goulding, models Alexa Chung and Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and video blogger Zoella.While all agreed to change their ways, none was taken to court where they might have faced fines or even jail time.“Influencers” might say the clue is in the name. They are paid to inspire you to buy stuff.Most insist they only endorse ­products they actually believe in — and we’d all hope they take their responsibility seriously.But it is easy to see how an offer of, say, £, to endorse something they “sort of” believe in might make it harder to hang on to those principles.Equally,guidelines aren’t strictly enforced, you can understand the temptation to convey the impression that you just happen to really like a particular laxative herbal tea, say, or a moisturiser that gives you a “glow”.It’s a grey area. And you might ask why it matters.But given recent news about the ­negative impact social media can have on the mental health of young people — and young women in particular — regulation of this brave new world affects us all.I need only point to another big story this week.Schoolgirl Molly Russell was  when she took her own le after showing “no obvious signs” of severe mental health issues.Her family later found she had been viewing material on social media linked to anxiety, depression, self-harm and suicide.Her father even went as far as accusing Instagram of “helping to kill her”.Social media makes it so easy to tap into someone’s daily le, their home-decor proclivities and their innermost thoughts.The intimate nature of Instagram lets you feel like these influencers are your friends, and the products they rave about their personal ­recommendations, not the outcome of a business deal.This is a real problem. But the mistake is much harder to makeadverts are clearly labelled as such.Part of the problem is how obsessed with celebrities our young people have become.When I was growing up, my main influenceswere my parents and my friends.Now, young people are influenced by people they will never meet.Some of these people, dare I say it, are talentless nobodies.You might argue you would have to be naive not to realise they are selling you something.Perhaps young people are not as cynical as the likes of me.And that is why regulation is key.IT’S hard to sympathise with Fungi, a “star” of hit telly documentary Benefits Street, who says universal credit is “the worst thing in the world”.Tracked down by this paper, James Clarkeclaimed his monthly payments had been more than halved and the all-in-one benefit was causing “hell” for him and others like him . . . because their booze budget has been cut.Fungi was claiming £ a month to spend on food and sundries. But this was slashed to £ – which doesn’t cover the £ a month he and his partner spend on strong cider.His rent, meanwhile, is paid in full via a separate taxpayer-funded handout.Fungi also says his drinking habit means he can’t work. Sorry, what Here’s another way of looking at it. People who work for eight hours a day don’t have the time to down three litres of cider a day.If Mr Clarke got a job, he might recover some of his self-esteem – and probably save his le in the process.Just to be clear – I BELIEVE in the benefits system.But it was invented to help people get back on their feet, to help those who can’t help themselves because of illness or disability.It should be a short-term measure, not a lestyle choice.In the meantime, the rest of us go to work to pay for this man’s rent and booze.All because he can’t be bothered to sort himself out.No wonder people get angry.In fact, I suspect most readers will have steam coming out of their ears.This man must start taking responsibility for himself.I SUPPOSE it was worth a shot for Diane Abbott to complain that Fiona Bruce was “badly briefed” and that her treatment as a list on Question Time was racist.But she can’t blame Fiona for her own incompetence in answering questions – and not just on Question Time.There are so many car-crash interviews to choose from . . . although the one in which Diane suggested police officers could be paid £ a year springs to mind.WHAT a nasty piece of work Dancing On Ice judge Jason Gardiner seems.We expect the judges to give feedback.And we know it won’t all be good.But his comment to Gemma Collins last week – “We are not going to see big lts from you” – came across as body-shaming.Because his real point is that she is overweight, right It’s shocking, really. I’m surprised ITV allowed it.THE secret behind Elle Macpherson’s phenomenal bod has been revealed.In an interview, she said it all comes down to . . . late breakfasts.Hmmm. No matter when we eat breakfast, most of us will never come close to looking how she does at .Actually, forget breakfast times. What struck me is her diet seems to contain just FIVE ingredients . . . one of which is nut cheese.And the only liquid is water.Elle looks great.But by God, she must be miserable.THE Premier League’s popularity continues to soar, as a study into attendances across Europe proves.And I was immensely proud to see West Ham ranked seventh by attendance in all of Europe last year.We are up there with the Continent’s elite, in a table headed by Barcelona.And that will only get better now the capacity of the London Stadium is up to , – adding to the incredible support we get from what I believe are the league’s best fans.This week, accountancy firm EY published a report on the impact the Premier League has on our economy.It generates £.billion a year in tax for the Exchequer, supporting , jobs and contributing £.billion overall to the country’s GDP.Last season, Premier League players paid more than £billion in taxes.But never mind the money.It’s still the best league in the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no delaying halting brexit john mann
story: Across the country people who voted dferent ways in the Brexit referendum are ­becoming bored and irritated by the silly games at Westminster.The truth is that a large majority of MPs are Remainers in their hearts and souls and are struggling to bring themselves to recognise the reality of the situation.It was us MPs who voted to give you, the people, the say on leaving or remaining in the European Union.And you voted, in higher numbers than you have ever bothered voting for any of us. Yet the same MPs who gave you a say are coming up with every excuse for why your views should not be listened to.Of course there are Remainer MPs whose constituencies voted heavily to remain.There are MPs with, I have to say it, courage, who have always argued strongly in a way that they have always known is dferent to their ­voters. These people are ­consistent and have my respect.But there are just as many who are in danger now of sitting on the fence until rigor mortis sets in, coming up with process rather than substance.They are simply hoping that others will do the dirty deed and respect the will of the people.It is also, for every Labour and Conservative MP, the manesto ­promise that we stood on at the last election. We voted for a referendum. We promised to respect the result.We got re-elected promising the same, yet Parliament continues to sit on the roundabout to nowhere.It is time to stop the shenanigans and work across the political ide to bring our country and our people together.At stake is our democracy. And in a democracy the winner prevails.Of course, in future years, people can argue that we have got it wrong and that people are entitled to change their mind. But for democracy to be true and real, we have to deliver the mandate we have been given and leave the EU on March .The referendum ided people and families, with lots of strong and dfering views. But in cherishing our democracy, we now need to come together to deliver a Brexit that respects the people’s vote and helps heal that ide.In le we have to compromise. We all have our own perfect Brexit, me included. And with ten of my colleagues we have forced through a big part of that, guaranteeing in law workers’ rights, health and safety and environmental standards. We will be competing with Europe by being the best, not by being the cheapest.I would love to have been a fly on the wall when Theresa May told union bosses that she was meeting their key demands not just with a promise but with a legal guarantee. But then she knew it was only right, because union members were the bedrock of leave voters across the country.And, I believe, we can get more in the next fortnight. A clear commitment to a once-in-a-generation investment into the Leave-voting areas that have long been starved of our fair shares — those former coal, iron and steel industrial heartlands, the unfashionable places, the areas still manufacturing. I think, as well, that union bosses and industrialists can be brought to act as advisers to the trade negotiations when we have left the EU, bringing their expertise into play to ensure a jobs-first Brexit for Britain.A country, proud and independent, standing on its own two feet, ­confident again in our democracy, bold enough to compete by being the best, British workers making high- quality products and delivering high-quality services.A country that says it will be the best by having better pay, conditions and a healthier environment than anyone  in Europe or worldwide.Is that not something to be confident in voting for, my fellow MPs  Let’s get on with it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cult of brexit remainer fading
story: I will try, but it is hard to see eye to eye with those who regard the .million who voted Out in  as pig- ignorant racists.Or to forgive Chancellor Phil Hammond for twisting Treasury data to undermine the British economy.I will simply wish him well in retirement at the earliest possible moment.Anna Soubry is a bit of a challenge too, but I will ­eventually find something nice to say.As for EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, even Her ­Eurosceptic Majesty would find little common ground with the man who vowed to punish her United Kingdom for daring to leave.But it will be cult-like Remainers who find it hardest to kiss and make up.Their hatred of Leavers has reached sectarian proportions.Astonishingly a poll found many would ban marriage outside the EU faith.Indeed, my old friendMatthew Parris insists Her Maj was wrong to suggest there is any common ground at all, because it might appear to endorse Theresa May’s dodgy deal.The Times sage has abandoned the Zen-like equilibrium which once made him ­compulsive reading. Along with the likes of megabucks Remainers Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and PR guru Roland Rudd, he seems to think Brexiters are basically pond le.That theory should be buried forever after this weekend’s passionate plea from leading academic Sir Noel Malcolm for MPs to stop wrecking Brexit.Writing in the devoutly pro-EU Financial Times, this distinguished Fellow of All Souls, Oxford, spells out the essence of the Leave case: “Brexit is about sovereignty — and parliament must respect that.”“If the UK is now on the brink of a constitutional crisis,” he adds, “one major reason is that a signicant number of MPs still oppose any version of Brexit, and seek a second ­referendum solely for the sake of reversing the decision of the last one.”Sir Noel does not believe people voted Out because they were racist.“The most important reason was democracy,” he says.“They wanted to live under laws made by the people they elected. Immigration came second.What they objected to was a supranational government ­making some of their laws and lting all immigration controls on the inhabitants of  other countries.”Another Remainer fiction is that Brexiters are narrow-minded Little Englanders.Yet the Daily Mail found space for a German view that Brussels should stop “insulting Britain” and honour us as champions of peace in Europe.“Such blinkered and sour responses are wrong-headed,” says Alexander von Schoenburg, a senior editor of Germany’s biggest newspaper, Bild.“They ignore the great debt Germany and the whole ­Continent owes our friends across the Channel.“We must always remember that throughout your history, independence and sovereignty have been paramount.“Germany in particular should tread lightly when it comes to dealing with your proud nation. It was Great Britain that first stood up to Hitler in .And it was Britain that opened its doors to thousands of ­Jewish refugees fleeing certain death during the Holocaust.“Put simply, there would be no free Europe without you and the bloody sacrice you made to rescue the Continent.”This remarkable tribute ­follows a recent love letter to the UK from Germany’s next Chancellor calling for a friendly Brexit orce and an end to bitterness.It is now clear hardline Remainers have over-reached themselves. The worm has turned.Talk of a second referendum is dead and voters are on the warpath against MPs plotting to scupper Brexit in tomorrow’s Commons showdown.Brussels is in chaos over the Northern Ireland backstop.Michel Barnier has started muttering about new tech- nology to police post-Brexit ­frontiers — a UK idea initially dismissed as “magical thinking”.EU allies are breaking ranks to demand a decent deal — for their sake as much as ours.It is way past time now for Theresa May to scrap the backstop and tell Brussels exactly what she needs to get her deal through Parliament.“There is absolutely no truth in speculation that ­passengers are being advised not to book,” stormed Brittany Ferries as it announced plans to INCREASE services.Meanwhile, mischief-making aviation giant Airbus admits it was asked by Downing Street to warn – incredibly – that it would shut up shopBritain left without a deal.Project Fear is shameless.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: this morning nta ally ross tv opinion
story: Six days a week now, This Morning hammers home the message its viewers are the most helpless, mollycoddled invertebrates on the planet.A form of le so useless that last November Dr Chris Steele, the show’s resident quack, genuinely felt the need to give us all bottom-wiping advice.“It’s a front-to-back action for women,” more of a hit-and-hope exercise for men.Infor this constant nannying, we pick up a phone once a year and gurgle: “You’re absolutely right. We are useless. Have a trophy.”And it’s a depressing cycle that will continue for as long as there are National Television Awards, live from The O.A ceremony where the categories may chop and change every year, but the stupidity remains ritualised.As well as getting all the usual winners though, viewers also had to endure a technical nightmare on Tuesday, where things went wrong — from the shambolic opening scenes right through to the unedited version of the closing credits: “With thanks to — Television Centre White City or just Television Centretoo long.”It’s always a case of fine margins, of course, at the NTAs, and the evening might have strayed into so-bad-it’s-good territorythe cameras had just focused on one of the Love Island gang when host Dermot O’Leary said: “Danny DeVito will be in Dumbo next year.”They didn’t, though. So a night bedevilled by sound issues, rotten acceptance speeches and foul Danny Dyer language was crowned by Special Recognition winner David Dimbleby eulogising the BBC and ordering us to be nicer to politicians, in a speech that could hardly be descri- bed as “mood capturing”.It’s the awards themselves though, that I know get viewers’ goats the most, starting, painful as it is to admit, with the fact perennial winners This Morning absolutely robbed Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain operation in the Daytime category.Given that Jack Whitehall’s Travels With My Father managed to scrape on to the Comedy shortlist, there’s also an argument that says Chunk, Charlotte Hawkins, Richard Arnold and Susanna Reid — who was styled quite magnicently on the night as Waitrose’s answer to Vicky Pattison — should have made that final five as well.Because almost no show made me laugh as loud or as regularly as Good Morning Britain did in .A glaring omission too in the TV Judge section — always won by David Walliams — which included X Factor’s Robbie Williams on the shortlist, but not Craig Revel Horwood, who didn’t take a two-week sabbatical in the middle of Strictly, cost the BBC £million or throw in his other half as part of the deal.The award that made a nonsense of the whole occasion though was Ant  Dec winning Best Presenters for the th time in a row, despite the presence of Bradley Walsh and Graham Norton on the shortlist, and the fact Ant spent far more weeks in rehab than he did in a TV studio.The mutual affection is touching in one way, of course, but it ultimately does neither them nor the NTAs any good at all and has robbed both of a glorious moment of redemption when they win the  award.Before that foregone conclusion takes place, please stay tuned to This Morning and sit tight until mid-March, when Dr Chris will be along with part II of his bottom-wiping masterclass: Flushing, FLU-SHING.Practially the only programme I watched at the weekend that wasn’t punctuated by uncontrollable sobbing fits from the participants was BBC’s landmark Holocaust documentary The Last Survivors.Men and women who are all in their late eighties and nineties now and understand that time is precious.When you’re a living part of history you also know facts are far more precious than tears.So in the words of the remarkable Anita Lasker-Wallfisch, who avoided the Auschwitz gas chamber purely because she could play the cello: “I won’t give people the pleasure of seeing my emotions.”The very least we owe all of them is an audience. The Last Survivors is available on the BBC iPlayer and will probably be the most unforgettable  minutes of television you’ll watch all year.At approximately : hours, Sunday, Gemma Collins stumbled over while Dancing On Ice.The tectonic plates groaned a little on impact, the front row scattered like ten pins and there was a surge on the national grid as several million viewers went “click, rewind, play,” then “click, rewind, play,” again.In fact, by the time I’d stopped rewinding and playing, Gemma had “bounced back,”and Piers Morgan, no doubt angling for a Le Stories interview, had claimed it was “the gutsiest thing I’ve seen on a talent show” – probably since the days Piers himself was wedged in behind the judges’ desk on Britain’s Got Talent.It was an undeniably great television moment, though.A proper face plant, with a full Klinsmann snow plough to finish.The downside, obviously, is that it’s guaranteed she’ll be back next week, when Melody, Wes, James and the others will be performing to a Fairytale theme and Gemma will be clearing the B Fettercairn to Banchory road,ITV want to find a proper use for her.Click, rewind, play.Things remain cheerful as hell on EastEnders.Alfie Moon’s car has been discovered near some clfs and a policeman has the job of breaking the most awful news imaginable to Kat and the Slaters.“Considering the location and the evidence at hand, we would suggest you prepare yourself for the worst.”Big Mo: “You understand what they’re saying ”Yes, bloody Redwater’s getting a second series. Stay strong, viewers.Celebrity Coach Trip, Roxanne Pallett: “I knew as soon as Jedward got on the coach it was going to be fun.”The One Show, Matt Baker: “If you haven’t seen The Greatest Dancer yet, watch it on the iPlayer. It’s well worth it.”And Icons, Kathleen Turner: “Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and smash social barriers.”No, Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and make people laugh.Tell the BBC to try it some time.Good Morning Britain, Piers Morgan: “Every cloud. We lost the NTA, but I got a kiss off Gemma Collins.” Yeah, every cloud’s got a gigantic p***-storm.No one from Peaky Blinders bothering to turn up to the NTAs to thank: “The best fans a show could hope for.”Celebrity Coach Trip contestants Jedward ­providing the finest argument yet for theof a hard Irish border.Sheridan Smith’s accent doing the London to Doncaster trip in . seconds flat, on that Cleaning Up tosh.The Greatest Dancer’s pre-performance sob stories straying horribly close to moral blackmail territory.And E fly-on-the-wall moron Vogue Williams asking: “Is Gandhi the Dalai Lama ” in total ­ignorance of this remarkable man’s wisdom, serenity and even his landmark campaign for Dolce  Gabbana’s Light Blue fragrance . . .Martin Keown: “It should be a great spectacle, so sit back, hide behind the sofa and enjoy it.”Phil Thompson: “You never know what’s going to happen and that’s exactly what happened.”And Paul Merson: “If he was at Arsenal doing this, he wouldn’t be doing it.”.This week’s winner is the bellowing great Orca herself, Gemma Collins, and Sugar, from Total Drama Island.Sent in by Rich, of Lincolnshire. Picture research: Alfie Snelling.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “At the  Olympics, what birds were first released as a symbol of peace ” Georgina: “Eagle.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “What is the name of the monument in Trafalgar Square built in ­honour of Admiral Horatio Nelson ”Gemma: “Pass.”Ben Shephard: “Which British comedian ­presented the television programme Backchat with his father Michael ”Linda: “Jasper Carrott.”And Ben Shephard: “The Tartan Army is the nickname for fans of which national football team ” Najam: “Newcastle United.”Najam. A word . . .ITV’s The Paras: Men Of War, evenit needed three more episodes and better editing.BBC’s The Last Survivors. Tom Jones singing Cry To Me, with the talented Bethzienna Williams, on The Voice.The sudden, joyful NTA realisation the old bald bloke with the white beard in row A was Tim Lovejoy.And Celebrity Coach Trip guide Brendan Sheerin telling Jedward, Charlotte Crosby, Roxanne Pallett et al: “Today, you’re all going to a donkey sanctuary.” Well it’s about time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Humble maths genius Jerry Selbee and his we Marge became multi-millionaires after he hacked the lottery and reaped the benefits for years.And after cracking the code to win millions, the couple are about to crack Hollywood after selling the rights to their story, according to CBS News.A big screen version of their incredible small town tale is apparently now “in the early stages of development, says the broadcaster, which featured the pair in a  Minutes episode.The down-to-earth couple were high school sweethearts, and raised six kids while running a convenience store in Michigan.They kept the store in their home town of Et for  years, before retiring in their early s to enjoy le a little bit.Back in , Jerry, who has a bachelor’s degree and a MBA in mathematics, noticed a flaw in the state’s new lottery game.The family man, then aged , realised in “about four minutes” that the new Winfall’s “roll-down” gimmick actually gave favourable odds to the player, prompting him to bulk-buy thousands of tickets at a time.Like other lotto games,no player guessed the six numbers required for the jackpot, the windfall would roll-over to the next week.However, in this particular game,the roll-over exceeded more than million then the jackpot would roll down to every single tier of winners - including those who correctly chose two, three, four or five numbers.Jerry, who is a lelong puzzle solver, realised that as long as no one guessed the six numbers on roll-down weeks, then a  ticket was statistically worth more than .He told the HuffPo: “I just multiplied it out and then I said, ‘Hell, you got a positivehere.’”After losing  on his first try, the seasoned mathematician persevered knowing that this was simply bad luck.On his next two attempts he won , from , worth of tickets and , from ,.He soon told his we Marge and they, along with their kids and close friends, started up a betting group GS Investment Strategies LLC in the small town of Et.The group bought hundreds of thousands of tickets every time there was a roll-down week and earned between .million and million .After Michigan shut down the Winfall game unexpectedly, Jerry and GS Investment Strategies LLC began playing Massachusetts Winfall game despite the state being  miles away.But after six years of playing and winning, Massachusetts lottery officials cracked down on group betting after it emerged that Jerrys firm and two other betting groups - including one led by an MIT computer genius - were dominating the states Winfall game, reports Boston.In , the Boston Globe was tipped off about their extraordinary success, and started investigating, suspecting initially that the game was rigged.Greg Sullivan, then state inspector general in Massachusetts, also became involved, and looked to seethere was any corruption or organised crime.But, he soon discovered that the couple had figured out a loophole in the state lottery game, and had won millions of dollars legally.He told CBS News that he was dumbfoundedly amazed that these math-nerd geniuses had found a way legally to win a state lottery and make millions from it.”Whats more, the state got very rich as a result, making  million courtesy of the high-volume betting.Prudent Jerry and Marge invested their winnings wisely, helping their kids financially, and payed for the education of their  grandchildren and  great-grandchildren.He also bought gold and silver coins in an anticipation of economic downturns, adding: I think devaluation of the dollar is a certainty.”However, theres been no flash holidays, new hot tub or even a sports car, as Jerry told CBS: We dont cruise.

title: nick timothy brady brexit vote
story: With the deadlock among MPs still not broken, nobody knows for sure what will happen.Theresa May says Brexit must go ahead on time. But she also says Britain will not leave the EU without a deal.And her deal — the only one on the table at this late stage — was defeated in the House of Commons by a record majority just two weeks ago.Tonight’s Brexit votes are not quite the final shoot-out between the dferent factions in Parliament. The Government has promised that MPs will vote soon on a new plan.Remainers and soft Brexit supporters in government are pushing to hold that vote as soon as possible.And MPs — backed by a Speaker who will rewrite any Commons rules to soften or stop Brexit — will force more votes on what happens next.Nevertheless, tonight’s votes do matter.One proposal comes from Yvette Cooper, a Labour MP.Her Yorkshire constituents voted to leave the EU by more than two to one and, during the election, she promised them she would “not vote to block Brexit.”Yet that is what her plan does:     MPs vote for her   amendment, they will be able to stop Brexit happening this year.Cooper has the support of several rebel Tories, soJeremy Corbyn whips his MPs to vote for it, she stands a good chance of getting her way.Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey, Conservative and Labour, have an amendment that calls on the Government to avoid a no-deal Brexit.Dominic Grieve wants MPs to control the Commons timetable, allowing Parliament to vote on dferent ways of watering Brexit down.Labour want to present MPs with options that include, predictably, a second referendum.Despite drafting a manesto saying “Labour accepts the referendum result”, the Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer says in a second referendum he would campaign to overturn the result of the first.It is possible that none of these amendments might pass.Remainers and soft Brexiteers are ided about what should happen.Some want to delay Brexit, some want to tie us to European rules and regulations, and others want another referendum to stop it altogether.Evenno proposal wins a Commons majority, the votes cast by MPs will probably demonstrate that there is a majority to water down Brexit one way or another.For Brexit supporters, this is very dangerous indeed.Some believe they simply need to run down the clock and, in  days, we can leave without a deal.For Leavers who want a negotiated departure, this feels like a serious risk.But Leavers who favour no deal need to ask themselves, can they really be so sure they will get what they want With several Cabinet ministers, many more junior ministers and a Commons majority against no deal, it seems increasingly likely that MPs will ultimately find a way of stopping no deal.When they do, Brexit will only get softer and softer.This is why the amendment proposed by Graham Brady, a senior Conservative, is so important.His idea is to approve the Prime Minister’s original Brexit deal, but with the “backstop” removed.The backstop is hated by unionists, because to prevent barriers to trade between Ireland and Northern Ireland, it creates new barriers to trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.And it is hated by Leavers, because it ties the UK to the EU’s customs union, and Northern Ireland to EU single market rules.Brady wants MPs to vote simply for “alternative arrangements” to the backstop.By avoiding a specic proposal, he hopes the amendment can win a Commons majority and, in doing so, demonstrate to Brussels that the deal they struck with Theresa May can be ratied — but only without the backstop.Critics, largely Remainers, say this is impossible.But in the past week or so, Angela Merkel has questioned whether the backstop is such a good idea after all.The Polish foreign minister has suggested it should expire after five years. And the European Commission effectively conceded that in the event of no deal, they would use policy and technology to prevent a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.In other words, they proposed solutions they once dismissed as “unicorns” and “magical thinking” when they were suggested by the British — and which could render the backstop unnecessary.But this is not all. Some European officials have floated, in private, a more inventive solution: that the UK and Ireland should form a British Isles customs zone, with Britain compensating Ireland for any new friction in their trade with Europe.So it is clear: whatever Remainers claim, alternatives to the backstop are technically and politically feasible.Recognising this, the Brady amendment would give the Government one last chance to negotiate something better.Yet Tory Brexiteers say they might not vote for it. They fear the ambiguity of “alternative arrangements” could allow ministers to negotiate an even worse deal, perhaps tying the whole of the UK to the EU’s customs union and single market rules for good.They do not trust May, her advisers, or most of her Cabinet and demand a specic time limit on the backstop.Butthey vote down the Brady amendment, they will not get what they want, and are more likely to get what they fear.As the clock ticks on and bottoms get even squeakier, MPs will coalesce around a plan to stop a no-deal Brexit.The EU will have no reason to compromise, and Parliament will soften our departure by aligning us with more and more European laws.If Leavers vote against Brady, they will be shooting themselves not in one foot, and not even in both feet, but in the head.As the Commons debates the proposals today, Leavers need to start compromising with reality. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. No excuses.”Guaido has continued to ramp up his challenge against Maduro, calling for anti-government protests on Wednesday and Saturday.Protests have already resulted in burned out cars, looted shops and deaths as civilians take to the streets to support the effort to oust Maduro.Maduro has turned Venezuela into an economic basket case during his five-year reign, with uncontrolled inflation hurting the lives of everyone in the oil-rich nation.Maduro was sworn in for a second term earlier this month after an election marred by an opposition boycott and allegations of vote-rigging.Since Guaidó swore himself in, China, Russia and Syria have all backed Maduro, with Russia warning America off military force.On Sunday, colonel Jose Luis Silva, Venezuelas top military representative to the US, defected from Maduros government.In a statement, apparently read in his Washington office, Silva said: Today I speak to the people of Venezuela, and especially to my brothers in the nation’s armed forces, to recognise President Juan Guaido as the only legitimate president.Guaido has said he will continue as interim president until a free and fair election can be called.Last week Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov told CNN: We warn everyone, not just the US, but some others that can entertain these ideas from this type of action.He said: The resort to military power would be catastrophic.

title: commons brexit vote theresa may drama
story: During an electric confrontation after summoning all Tory MPs, the PM pleaded for them all to support a senior backbencher’s unity plan.Mrs May threw the Government’s weight behind Sir Graham Brady’s call for the current Irish backstop to be removed to keep her deal alive as Parliament tries to seize control of Brexit.Giving it a majority in todays vote would “give a very clear message around what Parliament wants” and deliver her a mandate to take it back to Brussels, Mrs May insisted.But minutes earlier, arch-Eurosceptic Jacob Rees-Mogg declared his hardline European Research Group of Tory MPs would refuse to the unity plan.Instead, he demanded the PM spell out exactly what changes she would press the EU for.But that sparked a major split inside the ERG itself and a vicious bout of insults, as other members defied Mr Rees-Mogg to declare they would vote for the Brady plan.Boris Johnson also tried to pin down Mrs May during the tense meeting, several times yelling at her: “But what do YOU want to do Prime Minister ”The PM would only reply that she’ll continue to “battle away”.Loyalist Tory MP Simon Hart said: “Boris raised a question around, how is this going to manest itself in meaningful change.“She said, ‘we won’t know unless you support us Boris - get behind us and you’ll find out’.“It was the sparkiest that she was, and it got a cheer.”One Tory whip put the number of refusenik Tory Brexiteer MPs as low about  diehards, meaning tonights Commons vote will be very close - and Mrs May will need some pro-Brexit Labour MPs help.The DUP also kept No sweating overnight.Its  MPs, who are propping up Mrs May’s minority government, will meet today at .am to decide whether to vote for the Brady amendment, and what their terms will be for doing it.Asked whether Mrs May has the votes to win, one senior Cabinet minister told The Sun: “I think so”.Wavering Tory MPs said what the PM commits to in her final speech just before the pm vote will be crucial.Two other senior Tory Brexiteers, John Baron and Andrew Murrison, also withdrew their amendments to toughen up the backstop tonight, to give Sir Graham Brady’s a better chance of getting picked by the Speaker.No heaped pressure on John Bercow to choose the Brady amendment.ERG chief Jacob Rees-Mogg appeared to soften his opposition to the Brady amendment – just minutes after ruling out ever backing it.He had declared the ERG group would only sign up to an amendment tabled by the Government itself that promised to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement to remove the backstop or replace it with an alternative technological solution.But after the PM addressed Tory MPs he said simply a government statement explaining its new position on the backstop could be enough to win over his and the ERG’s support.Mr Rees-Mogg told The Sun: “It really depends on the Government –there is a new government policy and this is claried and it’s a government motion that’s one thing.“Butit’s simply a standalone backbench motion that means nothing then that’s another question.“It will depend on the tone of the opening statements.”The Brexiteer added: “There are people with dfering views on what it means. There is no great appetite for it but the appetite would changeit becomes new government policy.”As insults flew between Tory MPs today, one likened Mr Rees-Mogg’s hardliners to Millwall-style football thugs.The law states that after the deals defeat, the PM must make a statement in the Commons announcing her plans - which she did last Monday, saying she would press on with her current deal.The Government must then table a so-called neutral motion to be voted on - stating simply that the House of Commons has considered the statement made by the PM.Why does the vote matter Whether or not MPs vote in favour of the motion tabled by Mrs May is literally meaningless.But crucially, the motion can be amended - giving the Commons the right to pass any resolution it wants and dictate to the Government what it should do next.What are the amendments There are two main amendments - one from Labours Yvette Cooper which rules out a No Deal Brexit, and another from top Tory Graham Brady which kills off the Irish backstop.But another dozen amendments have also been tabled from across the political spectrum.Commons Speaker John Bercow will this morning select roughly half a dozen which will go to a vote from around pm.Most of the amendments arent legally binding but would provide a clear political message to the Government.But the Cooper amendment is legally binding - making it more worrying to ministers than the others.So what next Tonight’s vote is not a rerun of the first meaningful vote on whether or not to approve the Brexit deal.That is likely to come some time in February - whatever happens this evening.The PM’s former policy chief George Freeman branded Jacob Rees-Mogg’s European Research Group members as “hardline Brexit ultras”.He tweeted: “Everyone will have to compromise a bit. But hardline Brexit “ultras” need to compromise, too, to secure Brexit”.Issuing another appeal tonight, Tory party chairman Brandon Lewis said: “I would hope the ERG, when they look at this and actually look through the detail of what this gives the PM tomorrow, in terms of a meaningful vote that will come back later,it is about giving a message to Europe about what can go through Parliament in terms of dealing with the backstop issue and why that matters.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unlimited eu immigration no deal brexit
story: The Home Secretary said that any EU national coming after March  will be able to stay for at least three years – subject to security checks.Mr Javid said it was important in the event of a No Deal to be “practical” and avoid “sudden shocks for business”.Any post-Brexit border controls would only come into force from January  – as they would do under the PM’s deal.The Home Secretary separately scrapped the PM’s target to reduce net migration to below the “tens of thousands”.Challenged as he presented the Government’s Immigration Bill in the Commons, he confirmed there were “no targets” in his post-Brexit strategy.“In the white paper, which sets out our approach to the future immigration system, there are not targets,” he said.Border Force insiders last week said there was no way the UK would be in a position to stop free movement in a No Deal from April given the lack of any new customs infrastructure.They claimed it was impossible to dferentiate between EU nationals who already lived in the UK or those who should be turned away.Speaking yesterday Mr Javid said that in a No Deal, anyone would be able to come for an initial three months.They will then be able to stay for a further three years by paying a fee for European Temporary Leave to Remain – subject to identity and security checks. title: brussels brexit defeat irish backstop
story: Michel Barnier’s deputy, Sabine Weyand, accused MPs of ignorance about what is in the Brexit deal and said tech solutions to the border don’t exist.In a series of outspoken remarks that will cause consternation in No  she also blamed Theresa May’s secrecy for the unpopularity of the agreement.Speaking at an event in Brussels, the German eurocrat raised the possibility the EU will still insist on the backstop evenBritain opts for no deal.And she warned there is now a “very high risk of a crash out not by design but by accident” given the paralysis gripping Parliament.She said: “It’s quite a challenge to see how you can construct, out of the ersity of opposition, a positive majority for a deal.“The result of the negotiation has been very much shaped by the UK negotiators, much more than they actually get credit for.“This is a bit like snatching defeat from the jaws of victory.”In a swipe at MPs she said much of the debate in the UK “is uninhibited by any knowledge of what is actually in the Withdrawal Agreement”.And she added that amendments to be voted on about time-limiting or giving Britain a unilateral exit from the backstop were “like Groundhog Day”.Ms Weyand said: “This has been extensively discussed at the negotiating table amongst the EU.“The EU were unanimous a time limit to the backstop defeats the purpose of the backstop. although they want to limit the delay to no more than three months.The law states that after the deals defeat, the PM must make a statement in the Commons announcing her plans - which she did last Monday, saying she would press on with her current deal.The Government must then table a so-called neutral motion to be voted on - stating simply that the House of Commons has considered the statement made by the PM.Why does the vote matter Whether or not MPs vote in favour of the motion tabled by Mrs May is literally meaningless.But crucially, the motion can be amended - giving the Commons the right to pass any resolution it wants and dictate to the Government what it should do next.What are the amendments There are two main amendments - one from Labours Yvette Cooper which rules out a No Deal Brexit, and another from top Tory Graham Brady which kills off the Irish backstop.But another  amendments have also been tabled from across the political spectrum.Commons Speaker John Bercow will this morning select roughly half a dozen which will go to a vote from around pm - but most arent legally binding, and two of the amendments are seen as key.COOPER AMENDMENT - RULE OUT NO DEALLabours Yvette Cooper has teamed up with Tory ex-minister Nick Boles to try to take No Deal off the table.The cross-party amendment would force the Government to introduce a bill giving unprecedented powers to MPs.The House of Commons would be able to vote to delay Brexit by up to nine monthsBritain is heading towards a No Deal outcome.The bill states thatthere is no deal in place by February , MPs could then instruct the Government to seek an extension of Article, , the legal mechanism taking us out of the EU.Jeremy Corbyn backed the amendment today - giving it a good chance of success thanks to support from Tory rebels.BRADY AMENDMENT - DROP THE BACKSTOPSir Graham Brady is one of a group of senior Brexiteers whove tabled an amendment to kill off the Irish backstop.The amendment states that the Commons is prepared to back Theresa Mays deal, but only on condition the backstop isreplaced with alternative arrangements to avoid a hard border.Although it wouldnt be binding, Sir Graham says thatit passes it would allow the PM toto Brussels and secure changes to the withdrawal agreement.The Government is supporting the amendment and will tell Tory MPs they must vote for it.But its up to Speaker John Bercow to pick which amendments are voted on - so he could scupper Mrs Mays hopes by refusing to select the Brady one.Mrs May is pinning her hopes on a rival amendment from Tory backbench chief Sir Graham Brady.That motion would declare that the Commons supports the PMs deal as long as the Irish backstop is removed.Its still unclear whether senior Brexiteers such as Jacob Rees-Mogg will pile in behind the Brady amendment.

title: brexit minister makes crude joke
story: NewsBrexit minister makes crude joke about Dyson ball cleaner amid no-deal chaosChris Heaton-Harris, MP for Daventry, was slated for making schoolboy jokes ahead of tonights crucial commons votesShareCommentsByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  JAN NewsJunior Brexit Minister Chris Heaton-Harris made a crude joke on Twitter as parliament prepares for crucial commons votes "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email While most MPs are frantically preparing for tonights commons votes, one Tory junior Brexit minister had time to make crude jokes on Twitter this morning.Chris Heaton-Harris, who is a Parliamentary under-Secretary in the Department for Exiting the European Union, didnt impress his followers with his attempts at light relief as the Brexit chaos continues. The Conservative MP for Daventry took to Twitter at am writing: My Mate got one of those Dyson Ball Cleaners in the sales. Unfortunately, he misunderstood what it was for which is why Im now taking him to our local A  E. His joke fell flat with many of his followers calling him out for making schoolboy jokes when the government is in crisis.   One replied: Nice to see that with chaos about to engulf the country, entirely their fault, the Conservatives are concentrating on the essentials: schoolboy jokes. Another said: Have you really got nothing better to do  A third quipped about him calling the Dyson helpline in Singapore after Brexit-backing businessman Sir James Dyson announced the companies HQ is being relocated to the island city-state.  The bombshell announcement will mean Dyson is no longer a British registered company and Singapore will become its main tax base.The headquarter switch from Malmesbury, Wiltshire, proved controversial given that Sir James - the companys billionaire chairman, founder and owner - is an outspoken backer of Brexit .It is the second blow Dyson has dealt to Brexit Britain after last years announcement that it will manufacturer its new electric cars in Singapore, rather than the UK.  Meanwhile, MPs are holding another showdown over Brexit from pm tonight.The House of Commons will vote on a string of options for what happens next with Brexit - follow here for live updates. The most popular choices are to delay the  March date of Brexit or re-work the Northern Ireland backstop.

title: brexit plan b explained amendments
story: NewsBrexit Plan B options explained: All the amendments to Theresa Mays dealMPs are voting on the next steps for Brexit at pm on Tuesday  January. What they decide will change Britains future. Here are the options explainedShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan Bloom:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video commons-set-super-tuesday-brexit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMPs will get a crucial vote tonight on the next steps for Brexit. It comes exactly two weeks after Theresa Mays original, -page deal suffered the worst defeat in House of Commons history. Out of the ashes of that defeat, a string of radically dferent Plan B options are taking shape - and could delay Brexit. In total there are  plans, some of which will be selected for a vote by House of Commons Speaker John Bercow at lunchtime. MPs will then vote on whichever options are selected at pm on Tuesday  January. The result is crucial, because evenits not legally binding, it will give Theresa May a mandate and a plan to bring back to the EU. So what are the amendments that have been proposed and what will they do  Heres our rolling guide. The  most important plans If there are just three plans you have time to read about about, make it these. . Theresa Mays own Plan B - but the vote means nothing  Theresa May has her own Plan B, which is a lot like her Plan A. She wants to tweak her -page Brexit deal - including the backstop that could trap the UK under EU customs rules - and thento the EU for more talks. She could then make other demands depending what MPs say - and vote for. But the vote on her actual Plan B means nothing - this time. Instead MPs are only voting that they have considered her way forward. The real meaningful vote will be on an amended Brexit deal, thought to be before mid-February.  The key amendment by Remainers would force Theresa May try to delay the  March date of Brexit - taking No Deal off the table. It is being led by Labour MP Yvette Cooper and Tory MP Nick Boles. Crucially it appeared it would be backed by the Labour frontbench and Jeremy Corbyn - giving it enough support to pass the Commons. The amendment would give MPs a vote directing Mrs May to request an extension of the Article  date from EU chiefs,there is no new deal by February . Officially No are against the amendment, but Remain-backing ministers are believed to secretly support it because it will allow the PM to delay Brexit without getting her hands dirty. There are disagreements about how long an extension would be. No warned it could be nine months, Labour chiefs want three months. So Ms Cooper said that decision would only be made by MPs further down the line. Also, it would have to be agreed with EU chiefs anyway. WILL IT SUCCEED  It has a good chance. Labour indicated it would back the amendmentthe extension was cut to three months. But Downing Street said it would whip Tory MPs to vote against it - even though some ministers were in favour. The key amendment by Tory Brexiteers is to scrap a crucial clause called the Irish backstop - and Theresa May is backing it. The backstop, which could trap the UK under EU customs rules, is the main reason MPs defeated the -page Brexit deal by a record margin. So veteran MP Graham Brady led a group of Tories who said theyll change their mind and back the deal -the backstop is replaced with alternative arrangements. Crucially, with government backing Sir Grahams bid might just pass on Tuesday - which would send an ultimatum to the EU to think again. But the amendment prompted a huge row with Ireland, whose deputy PM said: The European Parliament will not raty a Withdrawal Agreement that doesnt have a backstop in it. Its as simple as that. WILL IT SUCCEED  It looked almost impossible. The government announced it was whipping MPs to vote for the amendment - but the hard-Brexit ERG group led by Jacob Rees-Mogg said it was opposing it. They apeared to be wobbling and would only make a final decision one hour before the vote. But Tory Remainers also called the amendment ludicrous, leaving it looking like it was doomed to failure.   Other major plans These are plans that have a fair bit of support, but either arent expected to pass, or are too similar to another amendment above. . Give MPs a say on all options - including a second referendum  Jeremy Corbyns amendment calls for Parliament to have a say on all the options. Theyd include Labours own Brexit plan with a full customs union with the EU, and also the option for a second referendum. Labour claims its version of Brexit which would include a permanent customs union, relationship with the single market and alignment on rights and standards could get a Commons majority. But Tory rebels are unlikely to back it. And a growing number of Labour MPs want the party to get behind a second referendum instead. Peoples Vote supporters hailed the amendment as a major step forward to a public ballot. But shadow minister Rebecca Long-Bailey denied it made a second referendum much more likely. And it was simply in line with Labours conference motion back in September , which called for all options to be on the table.  Tory MP Caroline Spelman has put down a very simple amendment that rejects the prospect of No Deal Brexit . The problem is, her bid gives absolutely no explanation of how the UK will actually reject No Deal - which is still the legal default on March . But that very same lack of detail has allowed MPs to unite around a single block No Deal amendment, even though they disagree about how to get there. More than  MPs from a range of parties including the Tories, Labour and SNP united to sign the amendment. . Let MPs choose between four ways forward  An amendment by Hilary Benn, chairman of the Commons Brexit Committee, would give MPs indicative votes on the way forward. MPs would choose from dferent options to see which would come out on top. They are:Another vote on Theresa Mays deal A No Deal Brexit Renegotiate the deal with EU to achieve a specic outcome A second EU referendum. MPs take control of the Commons timetable  Former Attorney General Dominic Grieve originally wanted a radical plan to let backbenchers take control of the Commons timetable - MPs, including five parties and  Tories, backed the proposal. But he watered it down to a much less exciting version after No branded it a coup. The new plan lets MPs take control of parliamentary business one day each fortnight between now and March . It is backed by MPs from across Parliament, including fellow Tories like ex-ministers Justine Greening and Sam Gymiah, plus Phillip Lee, Anna Soubry and Sarah Wollaston. The amendment states that on February  and , and March , ,  and , the first item of business in the Commons would be a motion on Brexit. Tory MP Anna Soubry said she would back a combination of the Cooperand Grieve plans, because put together, they can ensure No Deal is blocked and Parliament takes back control. Plans that have been ditched These plans have been dumped to clear the way for the Brady amendment . Demand an expiry date on the Irish backstop Tory MP Andrew Murrison tabled a short and sweet amendment to set an expiry date of  December on the Northern Ireland backstop. He claimed it could help get Theresa Mays deal over the line by appealing to moderate MPs who just want Brexit sorted. But the EU has repeatedly ruled out putting an expiry date on the backstop. So since drawing up this amendment Mr Murrison has shted his support to Graham Brady,whose demand to replace the backstop with alternative arrangements may have more luck. Kill off the Irish backstop Tory MP John Baron tabled a trio of amendments to dump the Northern Ireland backstop - none of which the EU would accept. His amendments would either kill off the backstop completely limit it to just six months or allow it to be terminated without EU permission. Needless to say the EU wouldnt accept this. And Mr Baron withdrew two out of three of his amendments, leaving only the one about terminating the backstop without EU permission. The rest of the plans These are the rest of the plans on the table. At the time of writing none looked like they would pass. CANCEL Brexit SNP MP Angus Brendan MacNeil is leading a bid to revoke Article  - cancelling the  March date of Brexit altogether. This because the UK can cancel Brexit without EU permission, but needs the EUs say-so to delay it. Put a Citizens Assembly in charge Labour MP Stella Creasy has proposed forcing the government to delay Brexit, with EU permission, and set up a Citizens Assembly. This new body would have a representative sample of  people to consider next steps. With help from the supergroup Liaison Committee, this Assembly would make recommendations to the House of Commons within  weeks. The government would have to respond within two weeks and set out how it will ensure the recommendations can be implemented in full. Delay Brexit II Rachel Reeves, the Labour MP, has an amendment to extend the March  date of Brexittheres no agreement by the end of February. It is a lot like Yvette Coopers amendment but would work slightly dferently. Labour were looking at whether to officially support it. Just like any plan to delay Brexit, this amendment would need the EUs approval. Prepare for a second referendum Lib Dem leader Vince Cable wanted to “instruct the Government to take all necessary steps to rule out a no-deal scenario and prepare for a People’s Vote in which the public will have the option to remain in the European Union on the ballot paper. Preparing for a second referendum is not quite like holding one. And its likely this would be rejected by MPs. The amendment disappeared on the day of the vote. Indicative votes The former Labour MP Frank Field has joined forces with Tory Ed Vaizey to give MPs a say on a iety of options. Their amendment would mean the Commons would have to allow time for a series of votes to act as a powerful guide to the government. The options would include:Reforming the Northern Ireland backstop Leaving the EU without a deal Delaying the UKs exit from the EU Canada-style future relationship Norway-style future relationship Customs union Holding a new referendumSet up a cross-party committee The Liberal Democrat Tom Brakes amendment would create a cross-party committee to take charge of the Brexit process. It would have power to decide when parliamentary time should be made available for Brexit debates and legislation, including on a fresh referendum with Remain on the ballot paper, to appoint special advisers, and to travel within the UK and to Brussels. Delay Brexit and rule out No Deal SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has an amendment to extend the  March Brexit date, rule out a no deal Brexit and call on the Commons to heed the votes of the Scottish and Welsh Parliaments. And finally... a plan that had to be ditched A second EU referendum  MPs pulled a straight vote on a second EU referendum after confessing it would not have enough support in the House of Commons. The cross-party group had wanted MPs to vote on an amendment calling for a new public referendum. But five days before the vote they announced they will not table the amendment - admitting not enough MPs support it. The group, including Labours Chuka Umunna and Chris Leslie, blamed Jeremy Corbyn - saying he should do the right thing and give unequivocal backing to a second referendum to ensure it can pass. Tory MP Sarah Wollaston said: We could have the numberswe had the unequivocal backing of Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour leadership. I think that is where we will get to eventually.

title: brexit theresa urges mps back
story: NewsBrexit: Theresa May urges her MPs to back new backstop plan - and slaps down BorisTheresa May ordered her Tory party colleagues to back Sir Graham Bradys amendment on the Brexit vote to help her salvage a dealShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsTheresa May wants ammunition to take back to Brussels to renegotiate Brexit"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa May tonight begged Tory MPs to back a plan to scrap the Irish backstop to give her ammunition to help her salvage her defeated Brexit deal.In a dramatic showdown, the Prime Minister instructed her party to get behind an amendment tabled by Sir Graham Brady for the crunch vote tomorrow night.But just six minutes before she made her plea, hardline Tory Brexiteers led by Jacob Rees-Mogg vowed to try to kill the amendment off .It came ahead of yet another Commons showdown over Brexit with dferent groups of MPs setting out competing Plan Bs for what happens next. Mrs May believes that she can push Brussels for major changes to the backstopshe is able to show that Parliament is behind her. After the meeting, Tory party chair Brandon Lewis said: “It does mean the PM can go back to Brussels and show there’s a Parliamentary majority for a deal that sorts the issue out.”   A No  spokesman earlier confirmed that the PM was prepared to ask Brussels to reopen the orce deal - despite them previously saying no.The PM also revealed that MPs would get another chance to vote on Brexit Plan Bs on February  and she will “battle away” to get her deal through.And she slapped down her former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson who asked what changes the Brady plan would bring. “We won’t know unless you support us,” she scolded. But the Brady plan was effectively left for dead after Mr Rees-Mogg said his pro-Brexit European Research Group of MPs had no plans to support it. Mr Rees-Mogg said that adding a legal codicil to the existing -page withdrawal plan was not enough. He said: “From our point of view, it needs to be a change to the text”. What happens next  The ERG wants the Government to bring forward its own amendment setting out the next steps by pm today. The DUP, which props up Mrs May’s administration, was also keeping No  sweating overnight over whether it will support the plan. But the EU closed the door on any further concessions on the backstop. Senior Brussels official Sabine Weyand said: “There is no negotiation between the UK and the EU. That is finished.”Ms Weyand, one of the architects of the Brexit agreement, warned there was a “very high risk” of an accidental no deal Brexit instead.“Crashing out is the only outcome that requires nobody to make any decisions,” she said. “We think we can handle it. I’m less sure about UK side”. Mrs May herself has previously warned MPs that Brussels would not be prepared to renegotiate. Mr Brady said his amendment - which would scrap the backstop in favour of “alternatives” to avoid a hard border - would give the PM “enormous firepower”. “If my amendment is carried, she goes back to Brussels and says - you wanted to know what we can get through the House of Commons  This is it,” he said.In what is shaping-up to be Brexit’s “Super Tuesday”, Labour was expected to back a move by Yvette Cooper to delay Brexit Day for at least three months.A handful of Labour MPs are thought to be against the plan, although co-signatory Nick Boles, a Tory MP, claimed it had “a great deal of support among ministers”. The PM will face down her ided Cabinet ahead of the vote and is expected to warn them they must get into line.

title: brexit uk reveals full immigration
story: NewsBrexit: UK reveals full immigration plan for EU citizens who arrive in No DealIn the event of a no-deal Brexit, EU migrants who arrive after March  will be able to stay in the UK for up to three yearsShareCommentsByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  JAN NewsHome Secretary Sajid Javid unveiled details of arrangements for the immigration system in the event of a no-deal "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The government has revealed its full immigration plan for EU citizens who arrive to the UK after March  in the event of a no-deal Brexit .EU migrants arriving after Brexit will be able to stay in the UK for up to three years in a no-deal scenario.If you are an EU citizen already living in the UK, heres everything you need to know about the EU Settlement Scheme.Home Secretary Sajid Javid unveiled details of arrangements for the immigration system from March ,Britain crashes out of the EU without a deal. For an interim period EU citizens will be able to enter the UK as they do now. But following the end of free movement, those wishing to stay longer than three months will need to apply for permission under a new European Temporary Leave to Remain scheme.   People who obtain this status will be entitled to live, work and study in the country for a further three years. EU citizens wishing to extend their stay beyond three years will have to make a further application under the new skills-based immigration system, which is due to be introduced from . Mr Javid said: If we leave the EU without a deal we will continue to deliver on the referendum result and end free movement once and for all - giving us full control of our borders for the first time in decades. However, we need to take a practical approach and minimise disruption to ensure the UK stays open for business. That is why we will introduce time-limited transitional arrangements and grant EU citizens coming after March  temporary leave.   But Alp Mehmet, vice-chairman of Migration Watch UK, criticised the plans. He said: This is free movement in all but name and is an astonishing concession before the situation of one million Brits in Europe has even been considered. Yet again, the government have completely caved in to the business lobby. Most of the public want a reduction in immigration not to see it prolonged for years on end. Under the proposals, applications for European Temporary Leave to Remain will be subject to identity, criminality and security checks. Applicants face being rejectedofficials determine that they are a serious or persistent criminal or a threat to national security.  The initial three months leave to enter will be free of charge, but applications for temporary leave to remain will need to be paid for. Fees will be set out at a later date. Non-EU family members who wish to accompany an EU national under the arrangements will need to apply for a permit in advance. Irish citizens will not need to apply for European Temporary Leave to Remain and will continue to have the right to enter and live in the UK under the Common Travel Area. Mr Javid also emphasised that the policy does not apply to those in the UK before exit day, whose rights to live and work will be protected by the EU Settlement Scheme. We want them to stay and value them hugely, the Home Secretary added.
