Key EventsBrexit will be delayed after Labour back key vote:Theresa May launches dramatic new battle with EU by vowing to RE-OPEN talks:Labour WILL back vote to delay Brexit:Whats happening today ::Disgraced Labour MP jailed for lying to police to avoid speeding fineIn other political news, disgraced MP Fiona Onasanya has been sentenced to three months in prison for lying to police to avoid a speeding ticket.The Labour MP for Peterborough was found guilty of perverting the court of justice following a retrial in December.Onasanya and her brother Festus were sentenced at the Old Bailey by Mr Justice Stuart-Smith this afternoon.Festus was sentenced to  months in prison for colluding with her to help her avoid a speeding ticket.Read the full story HERE. Fiona Onasanya has been sentenced to three months in prison and will serve half her sentence :KEY EVENTBrexit will be delayed after Labour back key voteBrexit looks set to be delayed after Labour confirmed they will back a key vote to extend the  March leaving date.The party will formally swing behind an amendment tonight by MP Yvette Cooper that would lead to the date being extended.With Jeremy Corbyn#xs full backing and several Tory Remainers indicating support, the amendment is now more likely than ever to pass.Labour still disagree about possible plans for a nine-month extension - saying it should be shorter.But Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell confirmed the party will back the amendment as a means of preventing a No Deal Brexit .Read more HERE. " content"https:www.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES sb _Jeremy-Corbyn-Visits-Middlesbrough.jpg"Labour are backing key vote to extend March  leaving date :PM confirms crunch debate on Valentines DayMPs reject dealTheresa May has confirmed the next major Brexit vote will happen on Valentine#xs Day. The PM reassured MPs that Tuesday#xs vote was not their last opportunity to have a say.She said the motion for a meaningful vote on the Brexit deal will be set on February  when there will be two days of debate meaning the vote could come on the evening of Valentine#xs Day.Mrs May#xs spokesman said: #xCIf we have not brought a revised deal back by February  we will make a statement and again table an amendable motion for debate the next day.#xCParliament will therefore be given the chance to have its say, whatever happens.#xD:PM backs Sir Grahams amendment to avoid Irish backstopOn Sir Graham#xs amendment to seek #xCalternative arrangements#xD to avoid the Irish backstop, the PM told ministers the plan had #xCa number of advantages#xD, her spokesman said.He went on: #xCFirst, it would make clear #xpassed that the will of the House is to leave with a deal.#xCSecond, it sets out in no uncertain terms our continued commitment to arrangements which avoid a hard border.#xCThird, it gives us scope for a new discussion with the EU about how best we achieve that.#xDMrs May warned her Cabinet that Parliament #xChas said on many occasions what it does not want the EU has asked what we do want and what this Parliament will accept#xD, her spokesman said.He added: #xCA vote for the Brady amendment make sit clear that current nature of the backstop is the key reason that the House cannot support the deal.#xDIn a thinly-veiled message to MPs not to back Labour MP Yvette Cooper#xs amendment which could delay withdrawal for the rest of the year, the PM insisted that tonight#xs vote #xCwill not be the last chance for Parliament to express a view on the Brexit process#xD.The Government will bring back a meaningful vote #xCas soon as possible#xD - butMPs again rejected her plan, ministers would table an amendable motion for the next day.That opens the possibility of MPs having a crunch debate on Valentine#xs Day #x the last day before the half-term recess.:Amendments selection delayedThe exact amendments to be voted on tonight were due to be be selected by Speaker John Bercow at pm.However, this has been delayed until .pm due to an urgent statement on HMRC#xs changes to its estate.:Malthouse Compromise is a recipe for no deal say Peoples VoteThe People#xs Vote have slated the Malthouse Compromise saying these proposals have already been rejected by the EU. The plan has two parts: #xPlan A#x would involve negotiating a new backstop and an extended transition period through to December that is rejected by the EU, #xPlan B#x envisages the UK entering an extended transition period anyway and paying the orce bill while offering #xno tarfs#x at the end of the transition period.Those campaigning for a second referendum say the plan #xCis a recipe for the no deal Brexit that the extremists have always craved#xD.:DUP backing Malthouse Compromise is naked attempt to deliver no dealOwen Smith MP has said the DUP#xs support of the Malthouse Compromise is a #xCnaked attempt to deliver no deal#xD. The Best for Britain supporter said: #xCIt#xs time for the DUP to get real. Coming out in support of the so-called #xMalthouse compromise#x conveniently forgets the EU#xs refusal to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement. #xCIt#xs not so much a compromise, as a naked attempt to deliver a no deal Brexit by reopening negotiations at the last minute - knowing that there#xs neither the time nor the political will for it.#xD:KEY EVENTTheresa May launches dramatic new battle with EU by vowing to RE-OPEN talksTheresa May wants to reopen the withdrawal agreement with Brussels in a bid to smash the Brexit deadlock.The Prime Minister told her Cabinet the only way to tackle the impasse was to amend the legally-binding document signed with the EU.Her deal was rejected by a crushing  votes in the Commons - and she has now admitted the pact needs to be changed to win MPs#x support.The EU has so far ruled out reopening the deal.But, following the Cabinet meeting, Mrs May#xs spokesman said today: #xCThe PM said that in order to win the support of the House of Commons, legal changes to the backstop will be required.That will mean reopening the withdrawal agreement.#xDThe PM is expected to hold phone calls with fellow EU leaders later today to beg for their support.Theresa May wants to reopen the withdrawal agreement with Brussels :KEY EVENTLabour WILL back vote to delay BrexitA shadow cabinet source has told the Mirror labour WILL back a bid to delay Brexit in order to #xCredcue the threat#xD of the UK crashing out of the EU without a deal. That would clear the way for the amendment by Yvette Cooper to pass just after pm. But theof delay is still up for debate. The source said Labour would not back a delay as long as nine months. And thewill only be decided at a later date.:Boris Johnson will support PMs Plan Bshe renegotiates Irish backstopBrexiteer Boris Johnson has said he will support Theresa May#xs #xPlan B#xshe promises to reopen the EU Withdrawal Bill and change the Irish backstop. The former Foreign Secretary said he will support Graham Brady #xs amendment calling for the backstop to be removed and replaced with #xCalternative arrangements#xD.At a meeting of Tory MPs in Westminster on Monday, Mrs May called on them to get behind an amendment He said: #xCIf the Prime Minister indicates in the debate that she will be pressing Brussels to reopen the Withdrawal Agreement to make changes to the backstop, I will gladly support the Brady amendment. #xCBut what we need is to achieve something legally binding - and that means part of the Withdrawal Agreement. #xCWe can#xt have some codicil or letter or joint declaration. We need to go back into the text of the treaty and solve the problem. That is the way to unite Remainers and Leavers in the Conservative party and across the country.#xDThe EU#xs deputy chief negotiator Sabine Weyand said on Monday that the bloc was #xCopen to alternative arrangements#xD on the Irish border but that Brady#xs proposal did not spell out what they were. Brady#xs amendment is not certain to pass, as a group of prominent pro-Brexit Conservative lawmakers have said they are yet to decide whether they will support it.Boris Johnson has said he will support Theresa May’s ‘Plan B’she promises to reopen the EU Withdrawal Bill and change the Irish backstop :What is the Malthouse Compromise Late on Monday evening it emerged a new Brexit plan had been put forward which is reportedly backed by members of both the Remain and Leave camps of the Conservative party. The plan - called the The Malthouse Compromise after Kit Malthouse, the MP who brought the parties together - would lead to Britain leaving the EU #xCon time and with a ing government#xD, former Brexit minster Steve Baker said. It would extend the transition period from the end of  and in to December  and allow the UK and EU to #xCprepare properly#xD for WTO terms or #xCobviate this outcome by negotiating a mutually beneficial future relationship#xD. DUP leader Arlene Foster has confirmed her party are in support of the compromise and wants the Mrs May to follow suit. #xCWe believe it can uny a number of strands in the Brexit debate including the views of Remainers and Leavers,#xD she said.#xCIt also gives a feasible alternative to the backstop proposed by the European Union which would split the United Kingdom or keep the entire United Kingdom in the customs union and single market. #xCImportantly, this proposal would also offer a route towards negotiating a future trade relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union.#xD Arlene Foster speaks to the media during a press conference to offer an alternative Brexit plan on January ,  in London, England. Dominic Raab and David Davis, two former cabinet secretaries who resigned in protest over Theresa Mays Brexit deal, appeared with Northern Irish MP Arlene Foster this morning to promote a revised withdrawal agreement they contend can win the support of parliament. " content"https:www.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES sb _Dissenting-MPs-Offer-Alternative-Brexit-Plan.jpg"DUP leader Arlene Foster confirmed her party is in support of the Malthouse Compromise :KEY EVENTWhats happening today MPs are holding another showdown over Brexit from pm tonight.The House of Commons will vote on a string of options for what happens next with Brexit The most popular choices are to delay the  March date of Brexit or re-work the #xNorthern Ireland backstop#x.Labour MP Yvette Cooper is also tabling an amendment to delay Brexit which would force Theresa May to take No Deal off the table.Up to  amendments could be selected - see our proper guide to all of them here - but in reality there will be fewer.The exact amendments to be voted on will only be selected by Speaker John Bercow at pm.MPs are voting on Brexit Plan B tonight More OnLabour PartyEuropean UnionHouse of CommonsTheresa MayYvette CooperJohn BercowPoliticsBrexit

story: NewsKate Middleton wears tartan as she arrives with William for Dundee visitThe Duke and Duchess of Cambridge were all smiles as they waved to onlookers gathered outside the VA Dundee design museumShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video kate-william-arrive-va-dundee-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have arrived in Dundee for their first official joint engagement of the year.Hundreds travelled far and wide to brave the rain and catch a glimpse of the royal couple. Kate opted for a Alexander McQueen green tartan coat, which she has been pictured wearing on numerous occasions - including in  when she visited her old prep school, Saint Andrew’s in Pangbourne. She also wore the stunning ensemble during a Christmas church service in Sandringham in . The navy and green pattern is that of Scotland’s rd Battalion Regiment, known as the Black Watch.Today the Duchess paired the coat with black gloves, black block heels, a Manu Atelier green leather shoulder bag and pair of Princess Diana’s sapphire earrings.The pair, who last visited the city in , are opening Scotland’s first design museum , VA Dundee, and greeting members of the public.The attraction is the centrepiece of a pound billion transformation of the Dundee waterfront, once part of the citys docklands. William , , and Kate , , the first royal patron of the VA, will meet the team who helped create the pound million venue which has garnered interest from across the globe.More than , people have visited the museum since it opened to the public in September, and today the couple are officially declaring it open. It was designed by Japanese architect Kengo Kuma and the building takes its inspiration from the clfs along the north-east coast and stretches out into the River Tay.   Meanwhile, the royal pair are also set to meet with workers from the Dundee Michelin tyre factory and join a meeting discussing plans to repurpose the site and create new employment opportunities. It has been earmarked for closure and around  people are facing redundancy. Last year, Michelin announced it would close the plant in the middle of .   Todays visit will build on Kate’s keen interest in promoting the visual arts, and highlighting the value that public institutions like VA Dundee can offer local communities, particularly in terms of increased accessibility to world- class art and design. VA Dundee director Philip Long said: We are honoured to be welcoming the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge to officially open VA Dundee. This official opening marks the beginning of a very exciting year, with upcoming exhibitions on videogames, robots and the future of design.   Through an eclectic programme, we aim to inspire people and provoke discussion about the role of design in everyones lives. The museums Scottish design galleries feature  exhibits drawn from the VAs collection, as well as from museums and private collections. It also hosts temporary exhibitions, with the current one, Ocean Liners: Speed and Style, running until February . Dundee Lord Provost, Lord Lieutenant Ian Borthwick, said: I am delighted to welcome the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge to VA Dundee. This magnicent building is continuing to raise the citys global profile and celebrates Scotlands rich cultural heritage. Dundee is a Unesco City of Design, a place where culture is helping to transform peoples lives. This museum has had huge benefits for the people of Dundee. It is continuing to bring tourism into our city, improve our reputation and create vitally important jobs.

title: laura plummer flies home after
story: NewsLaura Plummer flies home to UK after Egypt prison hell - after hinting she could Laura Plummer, , has hinted she couldto Egypt but is looking forward to a bath at her home in HullShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsLaura Plummer has flown back from Egypt "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Laura Plummer has flown home from Egypt after  months in an Egyptian prison for painkiller possessionThe Brit tourist was granted early release from her three-year sentence for taking  Tramadol tablets into the country. The -year-old said police had led her into the airport terminal, denying her the chance to say goodbye to her Egyptian partner Omar Caboo. She was then pictured on the flight home with sister Jayne and mum Roberta. Laura always claimed that the tablets, illegal in Egypt, were for Mr Caboos sore back.   Despite yesterday vowing never to set foot in an airport again after her ordeal, Laura has hinted that she couldto Egypt to see her partner. As she prepared toto Britain last night she told The Sun: Im so happy to be free from prison at last and coming home. I just want to get home and have a long bath and to get in my own bed. Its been like living a nightmare but one which I never woke up from. Its been a terrible ordeal for me and my family and to think its finally all over is overwhelming.   She said that Mr Caboo refused to give up on her and that for that reason I cant say I wont ever go back. Laura, from Hull, as arrested by Egyptian authorities on October,  , when she flew into the Red Sea resort of Hurghada from Manchester Airport. She claimed she was taking the tablets for Mr Caboo, who suffers from severe back pain, and had no idea what she was doing was wrong. Miss Plummer and Mr Caboo had an Orfi marriage, which is not registered with the state but allows them to share a hotel room.   She was initially charged with smuggling drugs, which carries the death penalty. But the charge was dropped and she was jailed on Boxing Day in  for possessing the painkillers. The Plummer family has previously said Ms Plummer had no idea that what she doing was illegal and was just daft. They said she did not try to hide the medicine, which she had been given by a friend, and she thought it was a joke when she was pulled over by officials after arriving for a holiday with her partner. A spokesman for the Foreign Office said earlier: Our staff continue to do all they can to support Laura and her family, and our Embassy remains in regular contact with the Egyptian authorities.

title: meghan markle prince harry wont
story: NewsMeghan Markle and Prince Harry WONT spend Valentines Day together - and heres whyThe Duke of Sussex, , will be in Norway on official duties on the most romantic day of the year - leaving his pregnant we at home in the UKShareCommentsByHayley Coyle:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsHarry and Meghan wont be spending February  together "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Harry and Meghan Markle won’t be spending Valentine’s Day together. It was revealed today that the Duke of Sussex, , will be in Norway on official duties on the most romantic day of the year. Kensington Palace tweeted that Harry will be visiting a remote training camp  miles inside the Arctic Circle on February . He will be there to celebrate the th anniversary of Exercise Clockwork in Bardufoss - the traditional name of the annual winter exercise that trains Royal Marines and Royal Navy sailors and airmen. The Palace also tweeted: “The Duke of Sussex will meet military personnel living and training on the base, view some of the specialist outdoor severe weather equipment and training that is conducted at Clockwork and talk with expert aircrews and engineers.”   The Duchess of Sussex, who is around six months pregnant with their first child, will be unlikely to join Harry on the royal trip as the visit will include spending time in one of “the world’s most demanding environments”. Meanwhile, a body language experts has weighed in on why the pregnant duchess is constantly cradling her bump. According to Harry Witchel it is the -year-old’s attempt at reserved royal behaviour. He told the Mail on Sunday: Meghan tends to cup her bump by knitting her fingers together – a sign of holding back and being more grounded.  Thats quite a contrast to her usual behaviour, which involves dealing with the world with gusto. As a Royal she is expected to be more reserved, so is this a subconscious attempt to be so  This doesnt look like acting. This looks like a woman aware of a change in her body. Meghan will give birth in the spring, but her exact due date has not been made public. The new arrival will be seventh in line to the throne, but it is unlikely that the baby boy or girl will be given the title of Prince or Princess. Instead they will probably become a Lord or a Lady as they are too far down the line of succession.   Ahead of the birth, Meghan and Harry will leave Kensington Palace and London and move to their new home Frogmore Cottage in Windsor. They are currently renovating the home, a present from the Queen, and getting the nursery ready for Baby Sussex. Meghan has reportedly opted for vegan paint and the design will be completely gender neutral as they dont knowtheyre having a boy or a girl.

title: mums horror after man grabbed
story: NewsMums horror after man grabbed son, , kissed him and said hes mine in town centreTerried um Sammy-Jo Thacker, , had to physically fight to get her son back - and thought he was going to be abductedShareCommentsByMellissa DzinziAndrew Gilpin:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsSammy-Jo Thackers son Erik, aged  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has revealed her horror after a man grabbed her son, aged , in front of shoppers before he kissing him and saying hes mine. Mum Sammy-Jo Thacker, , had to physically fight to get her son back from the stranger. The mother-of-three had been walking slightly in front of Erik when the incident happened on Saturday - in an incident which left her petried her young lad was going to be abducted. When she turned to tell him to catch up, a man in a white tracksuit stepped in between her and her son and grabbed him in an instant before kissing him on his cheek and telling the scared mum he was mine.   Single Sammy-Jo - who was in Doncaster town centre with her two other children, Elektra, eight and Elaina, two - fought with the man to get Erik back who initially held him tighter. Speaking about terrying the incident, Sammy-Jo said: This awful man tried to hold Erik tighter but I pulled him and just started shouting so loudly until eventually he gave him back to me.Erik was frozen in fear when I finally got hold of him - it was awful.Sammy-Jo says the effects of the incident has made her wary when she is out and is warning other parents to be vigilant.She added: This has really affected Erik - he used to be sociable and boisterous but now hes much quieter and prefers to sit with his head down.   He freezes anytime someone he doesnt know walks too close or walks past my window. Sammy-Jo admitted when Erick was first picked up, she was confused about what was happening. She said: At first I thought the man was a friend of mine when he kissed Eriks face but as soon as I heard him say mine I knew he had been grabbed by a complete stranger. I tried to get Erik and pull him back - three men walked past but no one stopped to help but I dont think they realised what was going on. My son was passed to my friend who I was with and he sat in the buggy frozen in shock and the guys mate appeared and they walked off smiling.  I tried to talk to Erik to let him know he was ok and Id never let anyone take him but he doesnt want to talk about it. Sammy-Jo is now looking to order a wrist strap with a small lock on the child size which can not be removed. She says she is struggling to sleep and Erik has refused to speak about it. The horric incident happened at Flying Scotsman Health Centre in Doncaster, South Yorks., and has since been reported to South Yorkshire Police. She said: I just hope hell forget what happened soon. Im hoping once he gets back to nursery he will be at ease - right now he is emotional. South Yorkshire police have been contacted for comment.

title: mum who lost 15 month
story: NewsMum-to-be who lost -month-old to sepsis terried she will lose new babyLittle Evie Crandle died from sepsis after Whiston Hospital in Merseyside sent her home with ibuprofen and CalpolShareCommentsByLaura ForsythKate McMullin:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsEvie Crandle with her parents Sam McNeice and Phil Crandle"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated mum-to-be is terried that she will lose her new baby after her -month-old daughter died from sepsis . Evie Crandles mother said she was broken beyond repair following the death of her baby girl in April last year. Samantha McNeice and her partner Phil Crandle took their baby to Whiston Hospital, in Merseyside with signs of sepsis, including a high temperature and heart rate. But as Liverpool Echo reports , despite being seen by a number of members of medical staff, she was not treated for sepsis until  hours after her admission. The youngster was instead sent home with ibuprofen and Calpol and died two days later on April  after being admitted to Alder Hey. An inquest into Evies death began at Liverpool Coroners Court yesterday. Here her parents claimed that their little girl had been let down in the worst possible way by medical staff. ■ Sepsis affects , people in the UK and kills , per year. That’s more than bowel, breast and prostate cancer and road accidents combined. ■ Sepsis is the body’s often deadly response to an infection. ■ Initially, it can look like flu or a chest infection, but it can swtly get serious. ■ Seek medical help urgentlyyou develop any one of the following… – are lethargic or dficult to wake – feel abnormally cold to touch – the skin looks mottled, bluish or pale – are breathing very fast – have a rash that does not fade when you press it – have a fit or convulsion In a heartbreaking statement, Samantha - who is nearly eight months pregnant - told the court, through tears, how she is petried she will again lose her baby. The inconsolable mum said: We are broken beyond repair. I have this baby on the way, due in six weeks and I am petried. Im scared she might get ill and no-one will listen again and I will lose her too. The mum, from Whiston, told the court how her daughter showed almost all the signs of sepsis. She said: She was throwing up from waking up, getting blue lips, cold hands and feet, she was very lethargic, had a very high temperature . and a fast heart rate . She wasnt herself at all. We explained to the nurses and doctors how Evie has so much energy and doesnt enjoy sitting on your knee cuddling, she is off playing and exploring and she couldnt do that. She couldnt lt her arms. She was trying to sleep all day. I asked why she was sleeping but her eyes were staying open a little. Evie never did this before.   Samantha, who had a picture of Evie in front of her throughout the inquest, said both herself and Phil knew the signs of sepsis and asked over and over about it. She added: We knew enough about sepsis to ask about it in the only place that could treat her, to identy the signs and ask for help fast. And our daughter was let down in the worst way possible. Shes gone from our lives forever. Young children and older people are most at risk - but ANYONE can get sepsis We cry every single day and I just cant imagine that stopping. She was so brave and so strong. Our lives were built around Evie, she was the centre of our universe. We have lost our daughter and have to face the fact we knew what was wrong with her. I feel like I failed Evie in the worst possible way.  Liverpool Coroners Court also heard from Evies devastated dad Phil, who said he cant bring himself to speak of his daughter in the past tense. Visibly upset he told the court, which was full with Evies friends and family: My daughter Evie is perfect. No-one knows her like her Mum and Dad, we love her beyond words can explain and will forever. She is exceptional and in her short  months and eight days you could see the beautul person she was blossoming into. So confident and clever, so full of character and cheek, so happy and always looking to explore and learn and more beautul that I could ever have imagined and so brave and strong at the end. Sepsis is a rare but serious complication of an infection. Without quick treatment, sepsis can lead to multiple organ failure and death. Early symptoms of sepsis may include:a high temperatureor low body temperature chills and shivering a fast heartbeat fast breathingIn some cases, symptoms of more severe sepsis or septic shockdevelop soon after. These can include:feeling dizzy or faint a change in mental state – such as confusion or disorientation diarrhoea nausea and vomiting slurred speech severe muscle pain severe breathlessness less urine production than normal – for example, not urinating for a day cold, clammy and pale or mottled skin loss of consciousnessWhen to get medical help Seek medical advice urgently from NHS youve recently had an infection or injury and you have possible early signs of sepsis. If sepsis is suspected, youll usually be referred to hospital for further diagnosis and treatment. Severe sepsis and septic shock are medical emergencies. If you think you or someone in your care has one of these conditions, go straight to AE or call .  We asked about sepsis straight away and even sat under a poster in the waiting room, we were told its more likely a urine infection by a band  nurse and felt such relief despite still feeling such fear. They could never let a  month old down, but they did. Liverpool Coroners Court heard how Sam and Phil arrived at Whiston Hospital with their daughter at around .am. However despite indicating signs of sepsis medical staff believed the youngster had a water infection and a urine sample was requested. The court, on the first day of the inquest, heard from three members of medical staff, pediatric nurses Kay Archer and Penny Hartley and Dr Jenner Hale. All three members of staff told the court how Evie did not present as a sceptic child. The court also heard how all members of staff had since had further training on sepsis, following the death of Evie. The inquest continues.

Joanne told herself she didnt need to worry about her weight while pregnant, bingeing on daily microwave meals, takeaways and six pieces of toast lathered with marmite. Determined to turn her le around for her family, Joanne joined Slimming World in April last year and has since dropped four dress sizes.   Now a svelte st lb, Joanne feels a million dollars and said her partner Stephen Grants jaw hit the floor at his th birthday party when she strutted in wearing a fitted jumpsuit. Joanne, from Thatcham, Berkshire, said: Its like Im a new woman, I feel like a million dollars. Im much more confident and better in myself. Its nice to go out and feel that people arent looking at you, or looking at you for the right reasons. People say whats your trick  but there isnt a magic wand - its about how much you want it. We went out for his th and I was wearing a jumpsuit. I came down to the hotel bar and his jaw nearly fit the floor. He said he was a lucky man and I looked stunning and he was really proud of me.  As of this week I can go into any shop now get a size  off the shelf and it fits perfectly. Its a huge dference. The mum-of-two admitted she used to gorge on takeaways and convenience foods during her -hour shts as a care assistant since starting their relationship in . After having son Noah Grant in March  Joanne said she soon felt embarrassed and inadequate when she struggled getting up from the floor at parent and child groups. It wasnt until after shed had Noah that the toll of her eating for two mentality was revealed as she spiralled to st lbs and spent months squeezed into maternity wear. I wanted to be able to get around like the other mums could and felt I needed to be thinner to give Noah the best childhood he could. Now I just tuck him under my arms and get up off the floor easily. Before Noah wed eat rubbish at home. Id be working  hours shts at the hospital and eating lots of takeaway, but I was only around a stone and a half heavier than I am now.   During pregnancy I thought oh, I dont have to worry about this for nine months, so Id eat six slices of toast with marmite for breakfast and the biggest cinnamon bun that youve ever seen. After having Noah, Joannes weight spiralled to  stone as shed suffered with pelvic pain and overeaten for months. Two months passed and trendy Joanne was still wearing her maternity clothes or struggling to fit into her size  leggings. Increasingly wary of her lack of energy and inability to play with her baby, Joanne ed to an old Slimming World class hoping to take back control. Joanne said: I wasnt always huge but I did pile on masses in that pregnancy. I remember going to my first midwe appointment and being mortied that I was already  st lbs. I had a horrendous pregnancy with swelling and a bad pelvis, and I was really inactive for the last trimester.  I was very immobile as well - obviously Id gone from working -hour shts three or four times a week, to basically being housebound. Everything spiralled, I wasnt mobile so Id sit and eat. I didnt have anything  to do, so Id sit and eat more. When Id had the baby and brought him home, I couldnt do anything. Despite previously trying Slimming World back in , her weight gain and embarrassment at being unable to move freely at the parent and baby group spurred her on to try the Thatcham group again.  Joanne said: I stuck to the plan religiously and now when I think to myself I want a cake I think I want the weight loss more. After getting back into Slimming World, Joanne began to cook family dinners from scratch and has enjoyed watching the pounds slip off. But the bubbly mum says she hasnt once stepped into a gym, crediting her slender shape to healthy eating and a short walk to the corner shop once a day.Joanne said: When I was pregnant I had horrendous heartburn so I lived on McDonalds milkshake.Now I fancy something like that or KFC, Id never go and buy one. I dont avoid carbs either. At night well have anything from a chilli, spaghetti bolognese, chicken kebabs, roast dinners - proper food. title: woman receives life saving kidney
story: NewsWoman gives a stranger her kidney after reading her plea on FacebookLouise Sach was diagnosed with renal failure and made her desperate plea to find a kidney donor - stranger Kayleigh Wakeling answered her postShareCommentsByDawn Collinson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsLouise and Kayleigh after surgery"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA year ago, Kayleigh Wakeling and Louise Sach had never met.One was a beauty therapist with her own business, the other was facing months, or even years, on a kidney transplant waiting list. But a Facebook post on January , , would change both their lives. Determined not to give in to chronic kidney failure which left her exhausted and suffering agonising headaches , Louise, from London, decided to tell her story on social media. Kayleigh, from Baldock, Herts, saw the post and felt moved to help – by giving one of her kidneys to a stranger. Now, seven months on from surgery, -year-old Louise is not only regaining her strength, the pair are best friends. They message and chat every day and, despite living  minutes apart, they meet up regularly. “We’re in this together, doing shyeverything as a team, which has been incredible,” says Louise.   Louise, who works in HR, was shydiagnosed with renal failure when she was just eight. “Every time I did any activity at school I’d pass out, be sick or get a high temperature, so that was a sign something wasn’t right,” she says. “Doctors told my parents both my kidneys were only working at around %. They were small, ing poorly and heavily scarred. They said I was never going to make it to shyadulthood with that set of kidneys. “I was unusual, though, because my kidneydidn’t decline for a long time. Although the tiredness and nausea increased, I was strong and stubborn, determined I would never let anyone see me as dferent. I came out of school with  GCSEs and  A- levels and did a degree in psychology.” After university, Louise went shytravelling, spending a year working in New York before moving to London. But in , aged , her kidneyplummeted to just %. The moment she had been dreading had arrived.   Family and friends offered to become donors, but the final three potential blood and tissue matches were ruled out. “Despite knowing for  years that this ‘end stage’ would come, I still had no donor,” Louise recalls. Next she joined the deceased donor list. “It was a long, terrying wait, jumping every time my phone rang in case it was ‘the call’.” But then one afternoon, having missed a friend’s birthday party because she was too exhausted, Louise decided to take action. She started a Facebook page and, in January , wrote a post telling her story, explaining the risks and the process of a transplant, asking anyone who might want to help to get in touch. Some , views and three days later, -year-old Kayleigh sent her a message. She says: “I saw Louise’s post when it was shared by a friend, and I’d never heard of altruistic donors before, but we are a similar age and I just thought, whatthat was me or someone in my family  “I was the same blood type as Louise, O shypositive, so I Googled to seeI could carry on normal le with just one kidney and everything I read said you could.”   Kayleigh and Louise chatted for a week on Facebook and instantly clicked. “There was no hesitation, I trusted her with my le,” says Louise. They met up when Kayleigh went to Guy’s and St Thomas’ Hospital in London for preliminary tests in February last year. Both admit they were nervous. “I was about to meet the lady who might save my le,” says Louise. Kayleigh says: “I was thinking, whatshe doesn’t like me  But when we saw each other we had a massive hug.” Two weeks later, Kayleigh found she was a match, and on June , the two had their shytransplant shyoperation. Louise says: “With a live donation, the donor goes to theatre then they send the recipient down to get ready so the kidney is only out for a minimum amount of time.” Returning to a ward after six hours of surgery each, they recovered in adjoining beds. Kayleigh adds: “I could see Louise looking better all the time, her skin tone changed colour. I was in pain from the surgery but seeing that every day she was getting better was the best feeling.” Now Kayleigh says the two women have formed a bond for le. “What’s happened because of that one Facebook post has been incredible,” says Kayleigh. “It has completely changed my outlook on le.” Louise is on medication to make sure her body doesn’t reject the kidney but says she already notices a dference. “Kayleigh and I would have been best friends regardless because we just clicked. I will be forever grateful for what’s she’s done for me.”

And with an ever decreasing number of young couples and children, the community has seen shops, restaurants and amenities shut and its only school is facing closure.Mattiet says he is willing to pay up to , euros - or pound, - over three years to families who make Locana their home. The mayor at first appealed to Italians or foreigners already living in Italy but after a disappointing response is now extending it to non-Italians living abroad too. Last year there were  deaths in the town, compared with just  births.He told CNN that working-age people have left the town in droves in recent years looking for jobs in Turin and other big cities. Roughly two years later, with Jiafeng keeping a dedicated vigil at her bedside through, Xiaoyu showed signs of consciousness. The first thing she is believed to have said was her boyfriends name.  The couple got engaged two years later and are now living a happy, married le in their hometown in eastern China. The incredible story took place between  and  in the city of Bengbu in Anhui Province. But it only became known to the public last year when Jiafeng was awarded by the Chinese authority for his dedication towards his partner. According to Chinese media, Jiafeng and Xiaoyu were classmates in middle school and the two fell in love in  when they were both  years old. In , -year-old Xiaoyu collapsedand was rushed to hospital. She was diagnosed with hydrocephalus -a build-up of fluid in the brain - and needed emergency surgery.  The operation failed, leaving -year-old Xiaoyu in a vegetative state, according to reports. Xiaoyus family and her boyfriend were devastated. But instead of breaking up with her, Jiafeng insisted he stay to take care of Xiaoyu. Xiaoyus mother, Zhu Jianmei, was reluctant to let Jiafeng shoulder the task at first and suggested Jiafeng should find a new girlfriend. Speaking to reporters, Ms Zhu said: His family are from rural China and his parents had sacriced a lot to nurture him to be a university graduate. In addition, on what grounds could we allow him to stay   But Jiafeng refused. He said he had chosen to be with Xiaoyu.  He gained the permission to accompany Xiaoyu after kneeling in front of Xiaoyus mother to show his sincerity and determination. Jiafeng told Chinese media: When I was accompanying her, I had faith that she would come to one day in the future. Jiafeng quit his job to be a full-time carer for Xiaoyu and fed her liquid food using a large syringe. Xiaoyus mother said she was grateful to Jiafeng after her daughter largely recovered. He claimed that one day two years later, Xiaoyusuddenly looked like she wanted to talk. Jiafeng said: Afterwards, she called my name. I felt so relieved - like the sun had come out after a storm and a heavy stone had dropped from my chest.   After Xiaoyu gained consciousness, Jiafeng and her family members brought her to seek medical advice in larger cities, including Beijing and Shanghai, so she could recover and walk again. The couple got engaged in  and married in . Xiaoyu, now , is still recovering and she cannot walk farther than  metres, needing medication daily. In a latest interview this month, the husband told Pear Video : on , I wish to work better and harder. I wish to look after my business in order to take better care of her. The couples biggest wish is to be able to have a baby one day.

story: NewsMum posts joke photo of girl with Downs syndrome - cant believe the responseOne photo of a young girl with Downs Syndrome sparked a career in modelling and turned her into an Instagram starShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsOne photo of Georgia Traebert sparked her career "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt all started with a joke photo, claims Rubia Traebert, the mother of -year-old Georgia Traebert. You may have heard the young girls name before -not youve undoubtedly scrolled past a picture of her face.Thats because Georgia, who has Downs syndrome, is a social media star, with more than , followers on her Instagram account.If that werent enough, the pretty teenager is also signed to five modelling agencies and has starred in ious commercials in her home country of Brazil. Speaking to The Sun, Rubia, , revealed how she accidentally kicked off her daughters modelling career. She said: During my pregnancy with Georgia, all my pre-natal exams were showing up ok, and we didnt have a clue she would be a child with Downs syndrome.Naturally at first it was a shock for us, but since the very first moment she was born she was received with a lot of love.It all started as a joke I posted a picture of her on Facebook and it was a hit straight away. The idea was to see how much it can inspire other Downs syndrome children.  Rubia explained that Georgia had always been lonely because other children her age dont have much patience with her. However she has found happiness in modelling. Georgia has always been very vain since she was little, she always liked clothes, bags, make-up and I always liked it too, so I believe she mirrored me, her mum said. I would parade her around, sing for her and I didnt know this would drive her career.   Despite her success on social media, Rubia admits there were times when it was dficult to continue posting photos online due to cruel comments. The hardest part was when I read some people post comments that she is only successful because of her blonde hair and blue eyes - Georgia is a very kind child and very talented, otherwise she would not have come so far. As well as modelling, Georgia hopes to one day become an actress or singer and is currently taking drama and music lessons.

title: dragons dens dundee man brian pitching for 80k tells tycoons he is proud of his city
story: A Dundee-born businessman failed to convince any TV Dragons to invest in his latest idea.Brian Irvine, , appeared on the latest episode of the hit show Dragons’ Den asking for an £, investment in his company.Brian is chief executive and founder of Firemizer, which is based in Nottinghamshire and, among other ideas, works to reduce household emissions.He grew up in Fintry and attended Linlathen High School before moving to the Midlands  years ago.Brian was trying to persuade the judges to give him the money in exchange for a % share in the business.At the start of his pitch, Brian told the judges he was very proud of his Dundee roots.He said: “My product was born in Dundee. It came about as the result of a conversation between myself and my father.“I tried it for two years before launching it.”Brian said the experience of appearing on Dragons’ Den had been very stressful and,given another chance, he would present parts of his pitch dferently.He added: “I got quite emotional at one point but it was a really interesting experience.“You get no rehearsal and you walk through those doors into a complete hotbed.“However, it was a fantastic experience and gave me a great deal of exposure.”Brian said that he developed Firemizer as a low emission alternative accessory for wood burning stoves, open fires and other open flame products to help households drastically reduce their particulate emissions caused by burning solid fuel, thus providing “guilt-free” use.He added: “It was actually dreamed up in a conversation with my dad in Fintry and I’ve been working on it and developing it.“The economic and environmental changes the country could see with this alone is phenomenal. We aim for Firemizer to become a household essential worldwide.”The product is a blend of stainless steel alloys which are welded together to create a grid which is placed on the base of a stove or hearth.It then reduces the “burn rate” and ensures heat is spread evenly across the fire and all fuel is burned.Brian said: “I also have other companies which the Dragons were looking for a share in.“I obviously wasn’t prepared to give them that. But I’m glad I took part even though it was very nerve-wracking.”

title: ewan gurr action needed to help dundee women using socks and newspapers during period
story: From its foundation in  until , I had the privilege of managing Dundee Foodbank.I recall one particularly memorable encounter with a young lady who had just accepted the food I handed to her.She pointed at the sanitary items and said she would not need any of them because she had not had a period for several months.Apparently, according to her GP, she was too malnourished.After helping to pioneer and manage the foodbank, alongside an excellent team of volunteers and trustees, I moved on to work with The Trussell Trust which joined forces with churches and communities to set up foodbanks to support local people experiencing short-term financial hardship.Every one of the  out of  local authorities where we had a foodbank presence provided sanitary items.In , my colleague Lyndsay and I arrived early for a meeting at the Scottish Parliament and decided to sit in the public gallery during First Minister’s Questions.Coincidentally, Labour MSP Monica Lennon asked how the first minister felt about voluntary organisations providing sanitary items to women and girls, before casually dropping the name of our organisation into the question.Lyndsay and I later contacted Monica, who had tabled a parliamentary debate to bring the issue to wider attention, and we agreed how great the need was.We had encountered many more women and girls on low incomes – not as malnourished as the young lady I referred to previously – who had supplemented the use of sanitary items with toilet paper, socks and even newspaper during their period.Other elected members joined the call and Lyndsay and I met Aileen Campbell MSP, who was the minister responsible for public health, to prompt the Scottish Government on universal free access.To the government’s credit, and thanks to the urgency of Gillian Martin MSP, a pilot was launched in Aberdeen in .The government later committed £. million to extend provision to educational facilities throughout Scotland.Last week, I was delighted to hear the government commit a further sum of £m to further extend access to libraries and leisure centres.It has also been inspiring to observe the efforts of others like Erin Slaven, Mikaela McKinley and Orlaith Duffy, the three incredible young women behind the On The Ball campaign, who have encouraged  football clubs in the UK to provide sanitary items free of charge at their home grounds.I still occasionally think about that young lady who came into the foodbank.I only saw her one more time, which was a fortnight after our first encounter, when she was referred to the foodbank for a second time.We were standing next to each other in a busy office and she squeezed my arm.I turned and looked at her and she said with a wry smile: “Since getting the food from here, things have gone back to normal.”

story: Midfielder Jesse Curran will miss Dundee’s Scottish Cup replay at Queen of the South today because of the hamstring injury he suffered in Saturday’s defeat against Motherwell.The Dark Blues are assessing the problem that saw Curran pull up with just five minutes on the clock at Dens Park.However, the fear is the Australian, who was limping heavily as he headed for the dressing-room after watching the first half from the bench, could be sidelined for several weeks.That would be a major blow for both boss Jim McIntyre and the -year-old who has made  appearances in an excellent first campaign as a top-team regular.Curran’s form has seen him monitored by his home country’s national team while Philippines manager Sven-Goran Eriksson has offered him the chance to be part of their set-up.He qualies for them through his mother and is also eligible for Scotland, where his father was born.“The physio is assessing Jesse and we’ll just have to see how he is,” said his club boss.Jim was left frustrated by the single-goal defeat against ’Well that came courtesy of a second-half penalty from David Turnbull, following a rash Ryan Inniss tackle on Elliot Frear.The gaffer, though, took consolation from the way his side dominated most of the play.“To say it was frustrating is stating the obvious because we put so much into the game. title: Call for Inverness to get a share of cash for shop conversions
story: CONCERNS have been raised that Inverness could be denied a share of funding to help the hardest-pressed local high streets turn empty shops into housing.Mike Smith, manager of the cityrsquos Business Improvement Districtfears a move by the Federation of Small Businessesto persuade the Scottish Government to split a pound million fund between the poorest-performing high streets only could see a relatively buoyant Inverness miss out.ldquoI donrsquot think thatrsquos fair, he said.ldquoAll high streets are under certain pressures. Retail is a commercial venture and we do not think that public funds should be given tosupport one retail sector against another.ldquoI think this pound million should be fairly split on a population basis and should be used in an equal way to improve the infrastructure.Mr Smith stressed that some local authorities will already be investing in this way and their successes ldquoshould not be held against them.He said the redevelopment of Academy Streetrsquos former Farmfoods supermarket was ldquoa good example of shops being turned into homes in the city with the local authorityrsquos support.The development there will include  one-bedroom and  two-bedroom flats as well as four retail and office units on the ground floor.A spokesman for FSB nationally said: ldquoIt is far too early to tell which high streets will benefit from this fund.ldquoWersquore making the case for each local authority to use this money in the places that it could make the most dference.FSB Highlands and Islands development manager David Richardson said: ldquoRather than spreading the money too thinly for it to have any impact, the FSB wants it to be focused on ersying our hardest-pressed high streets and is calling for local authorities to establish new co-investment funds to improve and convert existing properties. We must make more of what wersquove already got. Allied to this is the need for joined-up thinking amongst public bodies. Given that thriving high streets and village centres are inextricably linked to the health and wellbeing of their communities, it is important that all interested parties work in partnership.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister said she would be calling on colleagues to get round the table for some strategic planning to make sure the city gets a share of the funding.She believes the rate of shop closures in the Highland capital and the long waiting list for homes puts the city at the front of the queue.She said: ldquoIrsquom going to have a chat with the city centre manager, David Hass, and get people around the table to see how we can get our hands on that money.Tuesday  Jan  : PM
