But it is our intention to grow that business to about  jobs in the next few years.ldquoThe building at Daviot would also have an office for Brightcare. Itrsquos a well known building, bigger than we need for an office and there is space for both operations.ldquoI have already had expressions of interest from restaurant operators and a dog grooming business which would fit in well to because it is a popular area for people walking their dogs.Tuesday  Jan  : PM

title: Inverness charity issues go orange plea for fundraising effort
story: INVERNESS charity Leorsquos Pride is encouraging people to lsquoGo orange for a dayrsquo as ambassadors in this yearrsquos Muscular Dystrophy UKevent on February .The national campaign has been running for three years and has so far made more than pound, by encouraging schools, workplaces and iniduals to wear orange for a day and make a donation to MDUK.Additionally those taking part can choose to wear sunglasses or even set up a mock-tail bar, in order to raise funds.Leorsquos Pride is a local organisation which was set up for Leo Flett, who is three-years-old and suffers from Muscular Dystrophy . Leorsquos mum Louise said: ldquoThe support we have had since starting almost a year ago is absolutely incredible and we continue to be touched by peoplersquos kindness and generosity.Mrs Flett said: ldquoWe are totally blown away by this yearrsquos response. We have been very lucky and honoured to have been asked to be ambassadors for the day this year by MDUK which means a lot to us considering wersquore still so new.The charity is raising money to continue their work finding new treatments and campaigning for better care and support for people with muscle-wasting conditions to ensure them the best possible quality of le.Muscular Dystrophy UK regional development manager, Dean Widd said: ldquoA huge thank you to everyone in Inverness looking to take part in the national Go Orange for a Day on February . We are delighted that over a dozen schools, clubs, academies and businesses have registered to take part in support of our Scottish family fund Leorsquos Pride.Mr Widd said: ldquoIt is thanks to the incredible efforts like this that we are able to continue to fund pioneering research into potential treatments for muscular dystrophy as well as supporting families. With more than , people in the UK living with muscular dystrophy and other muscle-wasting conditions, it is important to do whatever we can to make a dference.Leorsquos Pride is also organising an event in April called Pride  after last yearrsquos event which made over pound,.Tuesday  Jan  : PM

title: Leading Inverness football figure to live on with launch of fundraising campaign
story: THE memory of a leading Inverness football figure will live on with the launch of a fundraising campaign to help renal patients and raise awareness of kidney failure.Sandyrsquos Army will be launched in memory of Sandy Corcoran, the founder of Inverness City Ladies, on what would have been his th birthday.Mr Corcoran, who died three days before Christmas, had lived with type one diabetes for many years and then developed kidney failure resulting in him undergoing long dialysis sessions in Raigmore Hospitalrsquos renal unit.His family, including we, Valerie, son Steven and daughter Ashley Mackinnon, plus five grandchildren, are now raising funds for the unit at a dinner dance featuring live music and comedians at the cityrsquos Kingsmillrsquos Hotel on April .At the stroke of midnight, Sandyrsquos Army will be launched heralding more fundraising events in the coming year.Mrs Mackinnon said just  tickets remain for the event after  were snapped up in three days.ldquoWe want the night to be a massive celebration and we want to remember what an unbelievable person he was, she said. ldquoIt is going to be a sensational tribute to him as a person helping others and he would have wanted it no other way. It will be a hard day but I feel that being with those who loved him it will make it easier.Although Mr Corcoran was diagnosed with diabetes  years ago, he managed his condition but then developed kidney failure five years ago.With the support of his family, he started home dialysis but when it became too dficult he had to swap to six-hour sessions three days a week in the renal unit.ldquoThe unit became like a family to us, Mrs Mackinnon recalled. ldquoThey were just incredible to my dad. I noticed he was never on his own. They work tirelessly  hours a day, seven days a week.He was due to have a kidney and pancreas transplant but then developed bone marrow failure resulting in him having blood transfusions which meant he could not have a transplant.Sadly, Mr Corcoran, who was also the manager of Inverness Precast, died on December . Over  people attended his funeral.ldquoHe faced everything with the most unbelievable courage. I never once heard dad complain, Mrs Mackinnon said.She added that the family want to give something back to the renal unit and, as well as the dinner, planned fundraisers include an ascent of Ben Nevis.ldquoThis is a way of helping others through his memory.Tuesday  Jan  : PM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Tuesday  Jan  : PM

title: New Lochardil hotel owner pledges to make investment
story: NEW owners of a well established Inverness hotel have promised more investment to make it even more attractive to visitors.Lochardil House Hotel has become the second mainland hotel bought by Skye-based Perle Hotels and the group has been advertising for staff to get ready for the summer.The Victorian mansion, which was built in  as the home of Inverness MP Charles Fraser-Mackintosh, has been a hotel since .It was previously owned by Eileen Fraser, who bought the hotel in . More recently she has expanded the hotel with the addition of a purpose-built banqueting suite, a conservatory restaurant, new kitchens and a separate  bedroom garden wing, more than doubling its accommodation provision.Perle Hotels marketing manager Nina Ghita said the group wanted to build on the hotelrsquos heritage and had no plans to change its name.ldquoWe want to keep those unique quirks and the history. Those are really important, but there are always things that can be improved, she said.ldquoWe focus on the Highlands and Islands and we invest quite heavily into the hotels, provide more jobs and just try and make something special within the area. The same thing will be happening with Lochardil. Obviously the hotel is in a really good position as it is. We donrsquot have any concrete plans as yet, but there will be heavy investment down the road.Unlike the grouprsquos previous hotels, which required major renovations, she does not anticipate anything so drastic. There are no immediate plans to add other north hotels to the group, but Ms Ghita pointed out there were opportunities available all the time.ldquoWe are a growing company, she said. ldquoThere will be future expansion plans but nothing concrete at the moment.Tuesday  Jan  : PM

title: Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds to play Inverness concert
story: They will perform at Bught Park on Saturday, June , as part of lsquoLive in the Cityrsquo, a series of summer music concerts planned for the city.Last year was a successful period for the former Oasis star, who landed a Mercury Prize nomination for the High Flying Birdsrsquo album Who Built The Moon , the bandrsquos third number one in a row. They also toured extensively across North America, Europe and Asia with Noel picking up the Best Album and Solo Artist accolades at the Q Awards.Joining the line-up for the evening, are two big names from the music scene. Indie rock band, Razorlight and Neon Waltz shy- from John OrsquoGroats - will be special guests on June .Local concert promoter, LCC Live is organising this concert, as part of its lsquoLive in the Cityrsquo. Carlie Davidson of LCC Live, said: ldquoNoel is a legend of the music industry, who along with his band, will take to the stage and deliver an array of classic songs from his career including recent hits Holy Mountain and Itrsquos A Beautul World.ldquoWersquore absolutely delighted to be organising his only Scottish outdoor show in  at our fantastic arena in Bught Park. It will be a great night and Noel Gallagherrsquos High Flying Birds, is a superb addition to our eclectic series of live concerts this summer.Tickets for Noel Gallagherrsquos High Flying Birds concert in Inverness go on sale at am on Friday from Ticketline www.ticketline    or in person from Cafferys Menswear, Eastgate Shopping Centre, Inverness, IV PP.Tuesday  Jan  : PM

title: Parents criticise new school bus service across Inverness
story: SCHOOL bus services have been in chaos since a council contract changed hands at the start of the month it has been claimed.Parents say a move to double up dedicated school runs with services for the general public since transport giant Stagecoach took over the Highland Council schools contract from DE Coaches on January  has seen pupils regularly forced to endure late-running and dangerously overcrowded buses.Police have also confirmed they are investigating allegations that pupils were threatened with a weapon on board a bus between Kirkhill and Charleston Academy on January .Mum Carol Paterson, whose daughter travels from Croy to Culloden Academy, said the problems are known about across Inverness.ldquoThe children at Croy are waiting sometimes up to  minutes in freezing conditions because the buses are now regularly late, she said.ldquoAnd when they board the bus there are not enough seats.Jools Lawson, whose daughter attends Charleston Academy, said: ldquoKids are regularly having to stand on a jam-packed bus or being put off altogether and told to wait for another one.ldquoThe service is disgusting and Stagecoach brush our complaints under the carpet.Posts from a private Facebook group set up for parents of pupils using school buses and shown to the Inverness Courier make clear the extent of unhappiness since the changeover.Other alleged incidents include children being put off a bus beside a busy main road without a pavement and two incidents involving Inverness Royal Academy pupils ndash one where a bus did not turn up at home time and another where the bus was too small to accommodate them.Highland Council has issued two separate statements in response to concerns raised ndash one with regard to a public service operating en route to Inverness Gaelic Primary stating it is unlikely to involve ldquoroutes which the public are likely to want to use and another on the Charleston Academy-Kirkhill route stating ldquomeasures have been put in place to make improvements.Despite this an online petition has been launched calling for the reinstatement of dedicated school services.Signed by almost  people so far it states: ldquoWhen putting our children on a school bus it used to be the case that it was only school children on these buses, therefore anyone travelling was accounted for and any incidents easily dealt with and tracked.ldquoNow we have opened the floodgates to allowing our children to be exposed to anything on these buses.Councillor for Culloden and Ardersier, Glynis Campbell-Sinclair, said Highland Council needs to launch its own investigation into whether there is a serious problem with how buses taking pupils to and from schools operate.ldquoThey cannot jam pack children onto buses like pilchards and hope there is not going to be an accident - especially in this weather, she said.ldquoEvery parent that sends their child to school by bus is depending on the council to ensure that happens safely.ldquoIt is the councilrsquos responsibility as corporate parent to ensure these children get to school safely.A spokeswoman for Stagecoach North Scotland said: ldquoSince we started operating the additional school contracts on January  there have been some issues with capacity we have identied and are working to resolve.ldquoWe are working closely with Highland Council to resolve these problems by issuing school children with passes allocating them to specic buses to prevent the overloading problems we have seen.She added that in terms of the issues raised by Mrs Paterson an additional bus is now running to and from Croy.Tuesday  Jan  : PM

title: Work starts on new outlets at Eastgate Shopping Centre
story: WORK has begun at the Eastgate Shopping Centre in Inverness to develop four food outlets.The units, suitable for restaurant or bar operators, are being created by the reconfiguration of two existing shops fronting Falcon Square.Burger King UK is the first operator to sign up while talks are ongoing with operators for the other units.In addition, a new kiosk will be created fronting the Falcon Square mall entrance. Possible uses include an outlet for a food takeaway.The development comes as the cityrsquos nearby rail station is set to undergo a pound million upgrade while a public consultation is currently ongoing into a bold vision to transform Academy Street to make it more pedestrian-friendly.Alasdair Murdoch, chief executive of Burger King UK, said: ldquoWe are excited to expand the Burger King brand in Inverness and look forward to welcoming guests to experience the great-tasting, high-quality food that has delighted Burger King customers for  years.Local building and construction company Compass expects to hand over the units in late May to be fitted out and managing director Thom Macleod is delighted it has been appointed principal contractor for the redevelopment of the former Monsoon and Mamas and Papas unit.ldquoHaving been involved extensively in the planning of the project, it is pleasing to now be making preparations for the works to get formally under way on site, he said.Previous proposals involved an extension into Falcon Square or rooftop bar but were altered to attract a wider range of operators.Centre manager Jackie Cuddy said it will be business usual while work proceeds.ldquoWe are delighted to see the works progressing after several enforced delays over the yearsshe said. ldquoThe market may have changed since we first started out on this journey but we are still optimistic that we can provide a great addition to the night time economy of Inverness with this development.Tuesday  Jan  : PM

title: docherty we have to be at our best
story: Stenhousemuir may be rock bottom of Scotland’s third tier but Pittodrie No  Tony Docherty insists the part-timers will be shown complete respect.Aberdeen are tonight set to face League One strugglers Stenhousemuir in the Scottish Cup fourth round replay.Following a - draw at Pittodrie, the sides will go again on the articial pitch at a sell-out Ochilview Park tonight.Docherty said: “Since the final whistle on Saturdayour full focus has been on this replay to make sure we do everything we can to get through.“There is nothing more important than this game tonight.“A bad result in the cup is when you go out.“We are still in the cup andwe do our job properly at Stenhousemuir we will progress into the next round.“We treat Stenhousemuir with the utmost respect and the realisation we have to be at our best to get through.“We did that in the first game as they are a good side and very organised against the ball.“They were very dficult to break down and were clinical in front of goal as well.“Stenhousemuir had one cross fromDonaldson andMcGuigan scored with a great header.“You can maybe look at our part in that but you also have to give real credit to the opponent.“We don’t expect anything dferent. The only dference is we are now playing on their articial pitch but we have a good record on those surfaces.”Aberdeen are set to be without centre-back Scott McKenna for tonight’s replay as the centre-back suffered a tight hamstring in the draw with Kilmarnock. The Scotland cap was sent for a scan yesterday. McKenna was out for six weeks earlier this season with a hamstring injury.Docherty said: “Scott came off with a tight hamstring so we sent him for a scan yesterday just to see the full extent of that.“He said it doesn’t feel anything like when he did it previously so hopefully the scan will clear that up.“Scott was out for six weeks last time and we are hoping it will be nothing like that.“However, you cannot be % sure until the scan and we find out exactly what it is.”On-loan Watford centre-back Tommie Hoban came on for McKenna against Kilmarnock.It was Hoban’s first game time since undergoing shoulder surgery in late August.Docherty said: “It is important you assemble a squad and we have Tommie Hoban and Mark Reynolds back to cover that area.“Tommie came on against Kilmarnock and he did well.“Between him and Mark we have cover in that area but we don’t want Scott to be out with an injury. Hopefully we will get positive news on that.”

title: council bike scheme stuck in slow lane
story: Plans to deliver a “Boris Bikes” style scheme in Aberdeen won’t move forward until at least September, it has been revealed.Opposition councillors have accused the ruling Labour, Conservative and Independent coalition of a lack of action around delivery of the proposed scheme.The SNP group said officers have confirmed any decisions on the project will not be taken until after summer at the earliest.Council chiefs were asked in March to begin work on bringing forward a business case around the introduction of a cycle hire scheme in the city.Councillor Jackie Dunbar, SNP operations spokeswoman, said: “I’m sure I’ll not be alone in thinking that  months to put together a proposal for a scheme to hire a bike is just a little bit excessive, even by the woeful standards set by this administration.“The reality is that a delay in a proposal coming forward is symptomatic of an administration which has spent the last seven years talking big but consistently failing to deliver.”The council’s ruling administration has claimed the proposals have the potential to bring a real “sea change” to transport in the city.Council co-leader Douglas Lumsden, who first revealed the scheme at last year’s budget, said the move follows the success of similar projects in other UK cities.The local authority hopes the proposed scheme, coupled with the proposed expansion of electric vehicle car charging points in the city, could reduce emissions and help the council progress its sustainable transport strategy.Council officers are hoping to finalise a consultancy brief, with a view to hiring a consultant after this.Once the study is complete, officers expect to report back to committee with the findings and recommendations of how to proceed.It is understood officers could take inspiration from the dockless hire bikes which launched in London last year.The bikes can be located and unlocked via a smartphone app and left at the user’s destination, rather than a docking station as is the case with the “Boris Bikes” scheme.Aberdeen City Council transport spokesman councillor Ross Grant said: “The administration brought forward proposals to develop a cycle hire scheme and we are delighted that our officers are working with the EU to bring about a cycle hire scheme that, importantly, will work for Aberdeen.“The people of Aberdeen have made clear that they’d welcome a cycle hire scheme for our city centre and it is disappointing that Councillor Dunbar is riding solo in her criticism when the rest of the council is riding in tandem with the aspirations of the council.”

title: no room for complacency say staff after aberdeen nursery rated very good by inspectors
story: Staff at a nursery have said they won’t become complacent, despite passing an inspection with flying colours.The boss of KingsWellies Nursery Kerry Robertson has expressed her delight at the report by the Care Inspectorate, which saw the facility given “very good” ratings across the board.Kerry said: “We’re really delighted because not only did we manage to achieve ‘very good’ ratings in all our criteria, but we also had no requirements or recommendations from the Care Inspectorate, which is quite rare.”Despite the success of the inspection, which took place in November, Kerry and her staff have written to parents at the nursery in Kingswells, assuring them they won’t rest on their laurels.Kerry said: “We’ve assured them we won’t become complacent at all. We’ll continue to improve because what we want to do is become a sector-leading nursery. And to do that we need to do our very best to continue to get better.”Kerry thinks the key to the centre’s success is communication.She said: “We’ve got very good communication and we really work in an open, honest partnership with parents and staff and we consult with them so we can continue to improve.”

title: possible traffic delays as aberdeens ultrafast broadband rollout continues
story: A number of Aberdeen roads are set to be closed to install ultrafast internet.The Cityfibre scheme is hoped to make Aberdeen the first city in Scotland to have web speeds of up to one gigabyte per second.As part of the scheme,  miles of cables have had to be placed under city streets.Some of the disruption caused by this work is now set to hit the Rosehill area of the city.Starting on February , roads in that area will face a series of partial closures.Morgan Road, Cairncry Avenue, Cairncry Terrace, Ash-hill Road, Cairncry Terrace and Ash-hill Drive are all facing partial closure until March .A subsequent batch of roads have also been earmarked for work.Ash-hill Place and Cornhill Drive are next on the list, with closures due toto Cairncry Terrace and Ash-hill Road before work ends on March .Along with the partial closures of the roads, a ban on parking will also be imposed on the affected streets between am on February  and pm on March .Aberdeen City Council has warned that any cars parked illegally will be removed and must be recovered at the expense of the owner.Meanwhile, Cityfibre is also set to shut down a street in the heart of the city centre.Exchange Street, between its junction with Trinity Lane and Guild Street, will be closed for the work between am on February  and February  at pm.The one-way restriction on Exchange Street will also be suspended during that period between the junction with Guild Street and Imperial Lane.

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: caravan caught alight sparks major
story: NewsCaravan which caught alight sparks major fire operationThe derelict property on Kilmarnock Road in Monkton went up in flames last Thursday night as the caravan attached to it caught fire.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  JAN NewsThe fire spread to the adjacent property "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA caravan which caught alight sparked a large scale fire operation as it set ablaze to a neighbouring house. The derelict property on Kilmarnock Road in Monkton went up in flames last Thursday night as the caravan attached to it caught fire. Four fire engines raced to the scene to tackle the blaze. And an aerial appliance was also mobilised by Scottish Fire and Rescue service. Firefighters battled the flames well into the night . The road remained closed after pm, eyewitnesses said. And a fire engine stayed at the scene the following morning.   One eyewitness said: “The house was right up in smoke. It was a big fire and luckily they got it when they did or it could have been worse.” A Scottish Fire and Rescue spokesman said: “We were alerted at .pm on Thursday, January  to a fire involving a caravan attached to a derelict property in Monkton. “Operations Control mobilised four fire engines and an aerial appliance to the scene, on Kilmarnock Road, where crews extinguished the fire, which had partly spread to the adjacent property building. “There were no casualties. “A single fire engine remains at the scene this morningto ensure the area remains safe.”

title: coventry city signing michael rose
story: NewsCoventry City signing Michael Rose can be future Scotland star, says Ayr United boss Ian McCallThe Ayr United centre half has completed a pre contract switch to the Ricoh Arena and will join the Sky Blues in the summer.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsMichael Rose, left, in action for Ayr United "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIan McCall reckons Coventry have bagged themselves a future Scotland star in Michael Rose. The -year-old has inked a two-year-deal with the Sky Blues after agreeing pre contract terms. And the highly rated centre half will join the League One giants this summer. Rose will see out the season with Ayr United before completing his lucrative move south. And Somerset boss McCall reckons the defender could even go on to eclipse goal king Lawrence Shankland - who is wanted by a string of top English clubs. He told the Ayrshire Post: You never want to lose players but Im delighted for the boy on a personal level. Everyone talks about Lawrence but, in my opinion, Michael Rose could go on to achieve just as much -not more -he wants to.  He is that good a player and Ive no doubt he can be a future Scotland international. For my money hes been the best centre half in the Championship this season. Of course wed have loved to keep him, but we have to be realistic. Rose is one of a number of players to reinvent their careers under McCall following his failure to break through as a youth at Aberdeen. And McCall said: It is further proof to boys thatthey come here and develop themselves, they will get their reward. Michael is an outstanding player with a very bright future and we wish him all the best. The deal was done quickly and professionally by Coventry and it means Michael can now focus fully on the rest of the season with us.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr United FCForfar Athletic FCScotland football teamScotland Us football teamAyrAyr News
