title: extended-gas-safety-wont-hike-up-waste-transfer-costs
story: BOSSES at Scottish Borders Council dont believe a long-list of gas-blocking safety measures for the planned waste transfer station near Galashiels will bump up the cost of the project.Since planning permission was passed for the pound. million station last year, supplementary reports outlining further protection have been submitted.The supplementary requirements for preventing toxic gasses escaping from the landfill into the planned building, gas dispersal gravel must be laid on top of capping materials.The requirements by DAM Geotechnical Services also include protection boards and specialist bolting.And specic seals are also to be integrated into the emergency sprinkler system.Stephen Milne, who is a senior environmental scientist, with DAM Geotechnical Services, stated: "The gas protection measures installation, integrity and quality are considered paramount as part of the overall remedial strategy. It is essential that the ground floor slab are effectively installed, with no defects and with suitable documentation."Increasing levels of methane and other toxic gasses have been recorded at the Easter Langlee landfill site in recent years.Data released by the Scottish Environment Protection Agency last month revealed , kilos of methane were sent into the atmosphere from the rotting garbage in ,  percent more than in .Environment bosses at the local authority believe the closure of the landfill site later this year and the opening of the transfer station will lead to a reduction in gas emissions.Despite the required new safety measurements during the building of the transfer station, they are confident costs wont increase.A spokesperson said: ldquoA remediation strategy was developed at the start of the project which included a series of protection measures such as a reinforced concrete slab with minimal service penetrations, granular capping layer with plastic vent carrier pipes and an impervious gas membrane.ldquoThe final part of the strategy is to provide an impervious surface around the access points."All of these measures were agreed and approved by the councilrsquos contaminated land officer and included in the recent supplementary report.ldquoThese remediation measures are nearing completion, with the final surfacing due to take place in March prior to the facility opening early summer."The cost of these works were calculated at the start of the project and form part of the overall pound.m project cost.

title: pets-play-in-memory-of-dog-georgie
story: A GALASHIELS dog owner is calling on Borders pet owners to enjoy a game offetch in memory of her four-legged friend.Lynsay Laird, who lost her retriever Georgie last year, has put a memory box containing tennis balls at the start of their favourite walk for others to enjoy.The bucket of balls has a photograph of -month-old Georgie taped to it along with the message: "Please take a ball and enjoy a game with your dog in memory of my beautul Baby G who loved this walk."Lynsay said, "I got the idea for the box after seeing it on Facebook. I had a lot of balls left because Georgie loved them and my other dog doesnt so I put them in the box at the Gattonside end of chain bridge."Since then someone has attached it to the gate and people have been borrowing the balls and putting them back and even adding new ones."I just want the box to remind owners to enjoy every moment with their dog."Georgie passed away in May last year after contracting Alabama rot, also known as Cutaneous and Renal Glomerular Vasculopathy .Only appearing to affect dogs, the disease damages the lining of blood vessels in the skin and kidney, resulting in ulceration of the skin and kidney damage.The condition can affect any breed or age of dog and a proportion can go on to develop severe, acute kidney failure, which is often fatal.Lynsay and her dogs Georgie and Taffy used to walk along the river most days and it was after one of these walks that she noticed Georgie had lesions on her legs."It was after a walk in Gattonside one Saturday that I saw that she had sores on her legs so I took her to the vet on Monday and she was given some cream."But she went downhill fast and by Wednesday her poo was black, which I later learnt was a sign that her kidneys were failing."I took her to the vets again where she was given a cone to stop her licking the sores but by Friday the vets suspected it was Alabama rot and put her on a drip and kept her in overnight hoping that she would improve."But on Saturday we were told that her kidneys had stopped working and she wasnt going to get better."I took Taffy with me to spend some time with her and then she got put to sleep."Alabama rot was first recorded in the UK in  and the number of cases has risen each year. Georgies was the first confirmed case in the Borders.Lynsay said: "The only way that you can be sure it is Alabama rot is to have a post mortem so Georgie was then taken to the Dick Vet in Edinburgh where it was confirmed that she had had Alabama rot. My other dog was tested for it but thankfully the results were clear."The Kennel Club is warning dog owners to be extra vigilant at this time of year as the peak season for the disease is between November and May.Caroline Kisko, Kennel Club Secretary said: ldquoAlthough the disease is very rare, affecting an extremely low percentage of dogs in the UK, the condition is very serious and potentially le-threatening. It is therefore vital that owners understand and recognise the warning signs, especially as time plays a signicant part in successfully treating the disease.ldquoWe are asking owners to look out for any signs of Alabama rot during the winter months and to remember to take action right away. Any dogs with unexplained or concerning skin lesions which typically look like sores, ulcers, or red, swollen, bruised areas, commonly with an infected appearance should be taken to their vet as soon as possible. These skin changes are usually found on their paws or lower legs, but may also appear on their head, face or lower body. Dogs who have contracted the disease may also become tired, disinterested in food, or present other signs of illness like vomiting or diarrhoea.ldquoAlthough these signs may not necessarily mean your dog has Alabama rot, acting quickly and speaking to a vet to determine what is wrong is the best course of action to protect your petrsquos health.While large amounts of research have been carried out over the last six years, the cause of the disease remains unknown. As yet, no evidence has been found to suggest that CRGV is caused by bacteria, viruses, fungi, toxins, or radiation. There is speculation that it is related to mud or water, due to the higher prevalence in winter and spring, and relatively low case numbers seen in the summer.Caroline continued: ldquoTo lower any risk of your dog contracting Alabama rot, itrsquos also advisable to keep your dog away from very muddy areas, wash wet or muddy dogs straight after a walk and regularly check your dogrsquos body for anything thatrsquos dferent.,params: .pushldquoWhile a distinct seasonal pattern is suggested, we must continue to research this deadly disease and ensure all dog owners are aware of the signs and symptoms so they are able to seek veterinary advice immediately.Despite what happened, Lynsay still s to walk Taffy along the river in Gattonside. She said: "There is so much fear about Alabama rot because not much is known about it. Its impossible to say where Georgie got it, she could have picked it up anywhere."We still walk by the river most days, we arent scared to walk there but I do make sure I get the mud off after.""My advice to other dog owners is to be aware and on the lookout for sores on your dog."

title: mammoth-catch-at-this-years-selkirk-haggis-hunt
story: MORE than  hunters headed onto Selkirk Hill at the weekend in search of the illusive haggis.And, as was forecast by organisers, they ed with a record catch.Glorious sunshine and crisp footing made for an excellent mornings sport.And for the first time in the historic huntrsquos history, woolly mammoth haggi were caught on the breeding grounds.Dave Scott from the organising committee told us: ldquoThe woolly mammoth haggi is an ancient strain of our beloved creature and they were plentul in Selkirk for the first time this year.ldquoFor decades it was thought they were extinct, but we have noticed more and more of these large colourful haggi here in Selkirk when weve been doing our inspections."There was a fear that theyd be like grey squirrels and scare away the smaller indigenous haggi but they all seem to live happily together."Were not sure why they migrated to Selkirk Hill but were happy to have them.ldquoEvery year there are more and more hunters but we are lucky having such tremendous breeding grounds that our haggis numbers remain fairly solid.As has become customary over the decades, the hunters were piped from the Market Place at .am.And, as superstition insists, the Haggis Polka was danced outside the Argus Centre to bring luck.Matthew Burgess, who took over as head huntsman from his late father Bob, made sure the strict rules were adhered to before toasting the haggis on competition of the dayrsquos sport.Mr Burgess told us: ldquoThere can be few better sights than  tartan clad hunters marching towards Selkirk Hill.ldquoOur forefathers maintained this wonderful tradition even when haggis was scarce, and their hard work has meant that today the next generation will never go hungry on Burns Night.Experts, many with with red noses, within the Townrsquos Arms hunt headquarters weighed in more than  haggi on Sunday afternoon ndash including more than  of the recently discovered woolly mammoth strain.Townrsquos Arms mine host Louise Stephen, who provided the pre- and post-hunt whisky toast, was delighted with the dayrsquos sport.She said: ldquoFewany left the hill without a catch. What a great day everyone had.

title: go-ahead-for-selkirks-first-gin-company
story: TWO couples from Selkirk have been given the go-ahead to convert an old workshop into a micro-distillery.Allan and Jane Walker, along with David and Susan Myatt, had applied to Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning department for permission to convert the Old Joinery, at Philiphaugh, Selkirk, into a place they can distil their gin.The foursome, trading under the name Selkirk Distillers, currently produce Reiverrsquos Gin, which is made using the whin flower as the main botanical ingredient, found on the lowland hills surrounding the royal burgh.Selkirk Distillers also produced a special bath of Bannock Gin, made using Selkirk bannocks from Cameronrsquos Bakery.Now, the group have been granted planning permission by Scottish Borders Council to build their own micro-distillery just outside of the town.Mr Myatt said: ldquoThe process produces no noise, makes no fumes as these are extracted to produce the spirit, and waste botanicals will be composted and used by the on-site gardens.ldquoWe are currently producing and selling out gin throughout the country."We currently produce at the Strathearn distillery in Perthshire.ldquoWe are now looking to move to Selkirk and produce in our own building.

title: the-spirit-of-burns-night
story: A KELSO micropub has created the worlds first haggis gin.Rutherfords will launch their new spirit on Burns night during their special Burns Lite event.The launch will see the gin piped in by local piper Sandy Devers before it is addressed by Jesse Rae, who will be in full regalia for the occasion.The CAMRA Borders Pub of the Year started producing their own gins in October .Owners Debbie and Simon Rutherford said: "We scoured lots of recipes for traditional haggis, and narrowed it down to the key spices which give the unique flavour."Then we set about experimenting until we came up with a unique, and very tasty, Scottish alternative to whisky."Our full-strengthHaggis gin is totally vegan, gluten free, meat free and utterly delicious when served with tonic."We can guarantee that no haggis, or any other animal, was harmed in the making."The new gin will be available to buy from Rutherfords Micropub and online at deliquescent. A cl bottle costs pound.

title: partying-gordon-student-was-almost-four-times-drink-driving-limit
story: A STUDENT who was caught drink driving in Kelso has been banned from the road for  months at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Eighteen year old Katie Marwick from Gordon was almost four times the limit as she headed home on the A road during the early hours of December .Depute fiscal Tessa Bradley said police officers were on mobile patrol when they saw a car being driven unusually slowly at between  and  mph and in an erratic manner.She continued: "The car was stopped and the now accused was slurring her speech. There was a smell of alcohol and she kept putting her hand up to cover her mouth. A roadside breath test proved positive."She was taken to Duns Police Station and gave two samples - the lower reading being  microgrammes over ."She made no reply to caution and charge."Defence lawyer Mat Patrick said his client had no previous convictions and the plan had been to leave her car at Kelso Racecourse following a night-out but she lost the people who were going to give her a lt into town and decided to drive herself.He commented: "She cannot over-emphasise her regret which is the totally appropriate response to this."Sherf Peter Paterson said he would have imposed a  months disqualication but reduced it to  months due to the guilty plea.In addition Marwick was fined pound which was reduced from pound due to the guilty plea.

title: funding-in-place-to-unearth-borders-12th-century-palace
story: AN archaeological project is set to unearth a Medieval palace in the Borders.Ancrum  District Heritage Society have secured funding for a pound, archaeological project at Mantle Walls.The historically signicant field to the east of the village was originally excavated in  by archaeologists from the University of Glasgow and local volunteers following a geophysical survey that led experts to believe the site is home to the remains of a bishops palace dating as far back as the th century.According to Historic Environment Scotland, the site contains the "buried foundations of a substantial stone building and associated buried remains that can be identied as the palace of the bishops of Glasgow at Ancrum."The latest phase of investigations into the history of the site is already underway with a project contract notice advertising for an archaeological firm being published last week.In the proposal for the  dig, Ancrum  District Heritage Society say the work will offer a signicant opportunity to contribute to the understanding of bishops residences as well as medieval Scotland and the medieval church.Part of the groups funding came from the Fallago Environment Fund which awarded pound, towards archaeological investigations of the medieval site.The site is now scheduled which means its protected from ground disturbance and unlicensed metal detecting.

title: eildon-receive-over-3300-bids-for-newtown-tenancies
story: LOCAL social landlord Eildon Housing have revealed that they received more than , bids for new affordable houses in Newtown St Boswells.The Selkirk-based provider has just completed the -property development on the edge of the village at Sergeants Park.But for every home that becameavailable for rent, there were over  applicants.Eildon chief executive Nile Istephan believes that recently being granted permission for a second phase of housing in Newtown, as well as a development at Huddersfield Street in Galashiels, will help ease the demand.He told us: "Housing need is a major issue across towns and villages in the Borders."People at all stages in le ndash from young people and families, to older people with care requirements ndash theyrsquore all looking for affordable housing."The Borders needs modern, high-quality affordable housing and the Sergeants Park development illustrates how Eildon is working closely with local communities, Borders Council - as part of their current Strategic Housing Investment Plan - and the Scottish Government to address this most fundamental of social and economic priorities.Of the  properties which have just been rented outat Sergeants Park,  percent went to local people.Four of the properties were built to accommodate special care needs.Work is now about to commence on the second phase of the development.As with the initial construction, Hart Builders will deliver the  properties.Managing director Andy Mallice told us: ldquoWe look forward to delivering the next phase of the Sergeants Park affordable housing development on behalf of Eildon Housing Association."These high-quality homes will be built to Silver Standard energy efficiency levels, providing residents with warmer homes that have fewer carbon emissions and are cheaper to run."Throughout this build, we will provide a wide range of benefits for the local community - including employment opportunities, schoolsrsquo initiatives and site based work experience.

title: study-finds-the-borders-is-a-broadband-backwater
story: THE Scottish Borders remains a broadband backwater despite millions of pounds of public money being downloaded into the area, according to the latest research.A major survey carried out by Which  has ranked the region as the tenth slowest out all  local authority areas in the UK.Only some of the most rural parts of Scotland and England, including Orkney, Shetland and the Highlands, fared worse when it comes to streaming services like BBC iPlayer and Netflix or carrying out online banking.And politicians are now demanding that the region is brought up to speed quickly before it falls further behind.Conservative MP John Lamont is among those wanting action. He told us: "Customers and businesses need to see some action fast."Poor connectivity is undoubtedly holding our region back and itrsquos a massive inconvenience for customers."For too long, residents in the Borders have had to put up with below par broadband."Given that we are so close to the central belt, having one of the worst average speeds in the country is truly appalling.ldquoPeople will look at this table and wonder why we have slower speeds than neighbouring Northumberland or Dumfries  Galloway or really remote areas like the Western Isles."Analysis carried out by leading consumer champion Which  of over , customer speed tests found that the Borders had one of the worst average speeds at .Mbps.Millions have been pumped into rolling out superfast broadband in the Borders.Communities around Ayton, Coldstream, Jedburgh, Stichill and Broughton were the latest to be hooked up at the end of last year.But many households are still without fast enough speeds for the basic internet services.Labour South Scotland MSP Colin Smyth, who is the shadow cabinet spokesman for Infrastructure, Connectivity and Transport, believes the Borders is on the wrong side of a growing ide.He said: "Scotland faces a digital ide with rural areas such as the Borders unable to access decent broadband."As this report exposes, the SNPrsquos roll out of fibre broadband has failed to deliver, with many people in our region receiving super-slow broadband rather than super-fast."Poor broadband speeds have a massive impact on local businesses who are being put at a competitive disadvantage and it is hugely frustrating for households who often canrsquot access services online because speeds are too slow and unpredictable."Itrsquos time we had a clear strategy from both the UK and Scottish Government to properly connect every household in the Scottish Borders to superfast broadband or we will continue to be left behind by the failure of both Governments.The Which  study found that six of the bottom ten UK local authority areas for broadband speeds were in Scotland.Which  managing director Alex Neill, said: "Itrsquos incredibly frustrating that so many Scots are still struggling to get a good broadband connection when so many of us rely heavily on the internet to carry out important everyday tasks."The Scottish Government must now press ahead with plans to provide  percent of the homes in Scotland with a decent broadband connection and make sure that no one is at a disadvantage because of where they live.Scottish Borders Council pumped pound. million of public cash into the BT openreach superfast broadband rollout in the area.And a study at the end of last year found there were major problems with the quality of the coverage.A spokesman for the local authority said: "Whilst that investment has helped contribute to the . per cent coverage achieved to date, it is unfortunately the case that many households and businesses in rural areas of the Scottish Borders are still unable to access genuine superfast broadband and the council continues to press the relevant organisations and governments to ensure that these premises receive this vital service as quickly as possible.The Scottish Government is investing pound million to extend superfast broadband access to all parts of the country by the end of .Local MSP Paul Wheelhouse, who is the Minister for Energy, Connectivity and the Islands, is one of the key speakers at a conference planned for April to discuss how Scotland can achieve superfast blanket coverage.

title: selkirk-youngsters-tv-show-set-for-a-second-series
story: A SELKIRK starlet has taken centre stage in a childrens TV show.Nine-year-old Mimi Robertson landed a lead role in CBeebies series Molly and Mack last year.Filmed last summer, the first series of the programme hit screens in the autumn and proved to be so popular with its audience it has now been recommissioned for a second series.The programme tells the story of eight-year-old Molly and her -year-old brother Mack.During the summer holidays, Molly is being looked after by a reluctant Mack who runs a toy and record stall in an indoor market called the Big Hub.The series follows Mollyrsquos fun adventures with Mack, her friends and the community who work there.Dad Mark Robertson said: "Mimi got the role by chance really. A friend flagged up that they were looking for someone to do some voiceover work for a TV programme."She went for that and spent a day doing some voiceover work. The woman who was in charge of that asked her to go to the open audition for Molly and Mack."That was in December  and we found out after that she got the part of Molly."Filming for the first series predominantly took place in Glasgow. Mimi said: "It was hard work, doing really long days, but I really enjoyed it and I learned a lot. I had lots of lines to learn and had a tutor on the days when I was meant to be at school."I also loved the Big Hub where the show was set up because it is a very special place with all the cool little market stalls to have adventures in."I enjoyed doing the filming in North Queensferry for the titles, although it was a bit chilly so it was hard to pretend not to be cold!"I was a very comfortable playing Molly because she is quite similar to me. She is very energetic, always has ideas, loves adventures, and whenever therersquos a problem she always wants to fix it.Dad Mark added: "I was more overwhelmed that she was - she took it all in her stride. She had a ball - she loved it."Aside from the children it was a real veteran cast and crew who had been doing tv and theatre for years. Mimi would come home and tell me what shed learnt that day."Mimi added: "It was cool to have my questions being answered on how they make TV shows - I always got to see how the cameras worked, how actors spend their morning before they go on set and how they did all their hair and makeup."With the family based in the Borders and the filming taking place in Glasgow, the logistics of Mimi working in Glasgow proved to be a family affair. Mark said:"The whole family mucked in to make it happen. We are not a stage or theatre family so it was all new to us."Were really proud of her and what shes done, its been a lot of fun."And its not just Mimis family who have been supporting her in her new role as a television star.Mimi is a pupil at Knowepark Primary School in Selkirk and her classmates helped celebrate her success with a special screening of Molly and Mack.Mimi said: "My friends didnrsquot believe me at first because no one had ever done something like this, but once we started watching episodes in class they believe me and are super supportive about it."The second series of Molly and Mack will begin production later this year.Mimi said: "I was very, very excited and glad that there is another series coming because I will get to see all the cast and crew members again, like the producer and director and all the chaperones."Molly and Mack is currently on CBeebies every weekday at .pm and .pm.

title: ae-figures-show-increased-waiting-times
story: THE number of people waiting more than four hours at Borders General Hospitalrsquos AE department has increased signicantly over the past year, new figures reveal.Data published by the Information Services DivisionScotland, an NHS body which publishes statistics on NHS Scotland, show that the number of patients waiting for more than four hours to be seen by medical professionals has increased by nearly a third.More than , people waited for more than four hours in , which is a .% increase on the figures from .Furthermore, the number of people waiting for longer than eight hours has increased by %, and the amount of people waiting for over  hours has increased by %.However, the percentage of people being seen within four hours has also increased over the  months, from .% to .%, meaning that while the number of people of waiting longer than four, eight, and twelve hours has grown, the vast majority are still seen within four hours.Claudia Beamish, Scottish Labour list MSP for South Scotland, used the figures to criticise the Scottish Government: ldquoScottish Labour has been concerned about the pressures on health boards for some time and these staggering figures expose the scale of the challenge NHS staff face in delivering patient care and how badly they have been let down by years of SNP mismanagement of our NHS.ldquoIncreasing numbers of people waiting too long at AE reveals unacceptable pressure in other parts of our health service such as in social care and primary care.ldquoWe already know that staff do not feel they are getting enough support and that the level ofunfilled health posts is unsustainable.ldquoI have written to NHS Borders to understand more about the underlying reasons for these increases.ldquoMinisters set the health service targets for staff to hit and then do not deliver the support andresources needed. It simply isnrsquot good enough.Rachael Hamilton, Conservative MSP for Etrrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, also criticised the Scottish Government, saying: ldquoNHS Borders staff work incredibly hard to care for every patient, but there is increasing pressure on services due to the decisions of SNP ministers who have led NHS Scotland into a workforce crisis over the last  years.ldquoScotland is to get a poundbn funding boost from the UK Government as a result of more cash going to the NHS in England.ldquoWe need to see the SNP stop the grievance politics and use the money effectively to ensure we see AE properly staffed and managed.However, SNP MSP Christine Graham, who represents Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, pointed out that Scottish AE departments are performing better than their close neighbours, insisting: ldquoScotlandrsquos AE departments consistently outperform their counterparts in England and Wales, however, the health secretary has been clear that no one should be waiting longer than they need to for treatment.ldquoIn the Borders, the number of people waiting for less than four hours in AE has improved from .% to .% since January , meaning that NHS Borders are beating Scotland-wide targets.ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos poundm waiting times improvement plan sets out action to improve clinical effectiveness and efficiency, increase capacity, and design and implement new models of care.ldquoThe Scottish Government also announced in the budget that poundm will go towards reducing waiting times.An NHS Borders spokesperson also pointed out that NHS Borders was beating the Scottish average, saying: ldquoWe work very hard to see people in a timely manner, and over the past  months we have managed to see an average of  out of  patients within the national four-hour waiting time target.ldquoDuring the same period, the national average has been  patients out of .ldquoWe recognise that health and social care across the country faced unprecedented challenges during winter   such as a long, harsh winter featuring lsquothe beast from the eastrsquo and high numbers of influenza and norovirus.ldquoThis did impact on NHS Borders and when we are caring for a high number of sick people who cannot leave hospital until they are well enough, it can take longer for us to see new patients arriving at our emergency department.ldquoThis is not what we would wish for the people of the Borders and we continually strive to improve our services so that we can provide prompt care to our patients.ldquoTo ensure our patients receive the right treatment from the right services we would encourage people to continue to keep the emergency department for emergencies by using their local community pharmacy, minor injuries units , and self-care when appropriate as well as phoning NHS  on  for advice.

title: santander-support-energise-galashiels-flag-day
story: COMMUNITY organisation Energise Galashiels are pin high after landing a funding boost from Santander.The international banking group, who have a branch in Gala, match-funded the cash raised at a golf day last year organised by the Machu Picchu Trustees.It was the th tournament organised by group and one of the beneficiaries of the August tournament was the Galashiels Trust.And helping out on the day were Claire Roberston, Shona Valentine, Mairi Lothian, Brooke Robertson and Louise MacCall from Santander.Jim Johnston from the Energise Galashiels Trust told us: ldquoWersquore thrilled that Santander are once again able to support the work of Energise Galashiels Trust, not only through their generous match funding contribution, but also with their staff volunteering for the Machu Picchu Trek Team Golf fund raising event."Wersquod like to pay special thanks to the team from the Galashiels branch for helping make the golf day a success and to the trustees of Machu Picchu Trek Team for their continued support.Santanders donation equated to around pound to Energise Galashiels Trust.

title: cross-party-support-for-leadburn-improvements
story: POLITICAL pressure is growing for major improvements at a dangerous junction on the edge of Peeblesshire.Tweeddale MP David Mundell is backing calls for a roundabout to be introduced at Leadburn junction.And he is being supported by local MSP Christine Grahame.The convergence of A, A and A between Peebles and Penicuik has been the site of several fatal crashes and many other serious accidents over the years.And drivers continue to report near misses around the junctions.With Conservative councillors controlling much of the power in both Midlothian Council and Scottish Borders Council, Mr Mundell hopes progress can be made.He said: "Whilst there have been recorded accidents over the years, there are also many anecdotal accounts of near misses, which are, of course, not included in statistics used for prioritising roads spending."Although the junction is just outside my constituency, Ive been happy to raise the issue with the appropriate authorities because of concerns raised with me by many road-users I represent."The lack of progress so far has been frustrating but Im a great believer that in politics perseverance over a long period can be necessary to find solutions to challenging problems."Thats why Im giving my full backing to Conservative councillors in both Midlothian and Scottish Borders councils who will be campaigning for improvements at the junction."Just over  years ago the historic Leadburn Inn was totally destroyed in a fatal crash.And campaigning has continued following further accidents as well as continued near misses.Local MSP Christine Grahame has welcomed the support of Mr Mundell, but wants more than just words.She said: "The Leadburn Junction has been a source of safety concern for local residents for many years. Irsquod welcome any action to improve it, but ultimately this falls at the feet of Midlothian Council.ldquoMr Mundellrsquos support is welcome, but as his Tory colleagues share the balance of power in Midlothian Council I, and indeed local residents, will want to see these words backed up by real action to improve the junction.

title: do-you-want-to-run-the-great-tapestry-of-scotland-centre
story: ITS being hailed as the best thing to hit Galashiels in a generation.And you could soon be running it.Leisure and cultural charity Live Borders is looking for a centre director to look after the The Great Tapestry of Scotland.The attraction is to be housed in a purpose-built centre in the heart of Galashiels with , visitors each year expected through the door.Created by renowned writer Alexander McCall Smith, historian Alistair Moffat and artist Andrew Crummy, the Great Tapestry of Scotland tells the countryrsquos story through  , making one of the largest tapestries in the world.The new building which will house the Tapestry has been designed by one of Scotlandrsquos leading architectural practices, Page   Park, while the adjacent former Post Office will be re-purposed to bring the B listed building back into use.There will also be retail, cafeacute, educational and temporary exhibition space, as well as an ongoing events and exhibitions programme.Jane Hogg, commercial director for charity Live Borders, said: ldquoThe centre director role for this new visitor attraction, which is planned to open in spring , is a brilliant opportunity for someone with leisure, cultural or hospitality sector experience to open one of Scotlandrsquos newest and most eagerly anticipated tourism destinations."This role will play a key part in delivering the target of bringing the ,-plus visitors we want to attract to Galashiels, as well working in collaboration with the wider community we want everyone to be proud of this landmark project."The Great Tapestry of Scotland is a phenomenal achievement and this new visitor experience will celebrate the creative talents of the army of , stitchers, the story of Scotland, and its people it is a triumph of creativity, skill, community and patience."Work on the Tapestry building is due to begin this spring.The visitor attraction is seen as a catalyst for the regeneration of Galashiels.Experts predict that the centre will attract over , people to Galashiels each year once opened, as well as create  jobs.Almost pound, of extra spending per year is predicted for the local economy, providing , extra visits to complementary attractions, supporting a further  jobs.Business councillor Mark Rowley said: ldquoThe Great Tapestry of Scotland will not only create a national destination visitor attraction and signicant community facility in the Borders, it is also playing a key role in the regeneration of Galashiels.ldquoWith the Borders Railway on its doorstep, we also have the prospect of the Tapestry attracting thousands of visitors from Edinburgh to discover the wider Borders.ldquoThe Centre Director is therefore a key and exciting role for the whole of the Borders, providing the successful candidate with the opportunity to work in partnership with community and business groups, Live Borders, the Council and Energise Galashiels Trust to make a real dference in the town and the region.The closing date for applications is Friday, February .To request a an application pack email recruitment@Liveborders.org.uk quoting job reference .Interviews are expected to be held later in February.

title: britains-got-talent-stars-set-to-astound-macarts
story: How did they do that The response is the only understandable part of mind-reading double act DNAs amazing new stage show.And straight from the Britains Got Talent hall of fame they are bringing their beyond-belief telepathic abilities to Galashiels.It was during the Britains Got Talent auditions in  that DNA, better known as Andrew and Darren, wowed Simon Cowell, Amanda Holden, David Walliams and Alesha Dixon as well as million watching at home.They made it through to the final with their unexplainable mind-reading abilities.And their performance was to go on and be viewed more than  million times on YouTube alone.Whats incredible on television is even more astounding when seen live.And you can witness it for yourselves when DNA appear at MacArts on Sunday, February .A spokeswoman for MacArts told us: "Performed completely live, they can ask volunteers to concentrate on the name of celebrities, telephone numbers, credit card numbers, a word in a book, the name of the street they grew up on, a relativersquos name... literally anything."With devastating speed and accuracy, the pair are then able to reveal what that name, number or word is, every time."Their unique mind reading performances have now been enjoyed by tens of millions of people around the world."Aptly named rsquoThe Gtrsquo, the duo have created a show that will blow minds and prove that the impossible really is possible - but only for them!"This brand new show features world exclusive, never before seen material that is being showcased for the very first time!"DNA will perform at the MacArts centre as part of a nationwide tour throughout the UK.Tickets, priced at pound, for the show on Sunday, February  are available from the MacArts box office on    or from www.ticketsource macartsDoors open at .pm.

title: its-all-app-ening-down-the-library
story: LIBRARY users in the Borders can now reserve and renew items, check opening times and more through an easy-to-use app.Via the lsquoIguanarsquo app, library members in the region can search and reserve items, cancel reservations, renew items on loan, view payments due, and even create a lsquowish listrsquo of books they would like to read.Cameron McAulay, digital and media officer service officer at Live Borders, said: If yoursquore out and about and find yourself in a bookshop, you can scan a bookrsquos ISBN barcode and check whether your library has a copy."As I always say, lsquoWhy buy when you can borrow rsquoFrom mobile phones, tablets and computers, you can send emails to your local branch from the app.And,you use the app via your mobile phone, you can make phone calls to a branch with one click.The Iguana app is a useful addition to Live Borders library services and along with the apps for eAudiobook, eBooks, eMagazines and eComics.Cameron added: ldquoWersquore constantly striving to offer the best possible access to our libraries, both in terms of physical spaces, and our virtual library s."And, wersquore hoping the app will encourage more busy people to use their local library"One of the barriers to using libraries is the fear of being fined for having overdue books. With the app, users receive push notications for loans nearing their expiry date."And, as you can renew resources via the app, you should never need to worry about an overdue fee again."To access all the features, download the lsquoIguanarsquo app on your device and enter your pin to get started.The app also links to Google Maps, which meanssomeone does not know where their local library is or how to get there, they can look up directions via the app.

title: unemployed-young-borderers-offered-a-sporting-chance-by-live-borders
story: UP to  unemployed Borders are to be given a sporting chance in the job market.A successful funding bid to the Year of Young People National Lottery Fund has allowed local charity, Live Borders to launch a new employability programme.LIVE My Future is a -week scheme for young people aged between  and  who live in the region and are currently unemployed and who are not in education or training.The aim of LIVE My Future is to boost their employment by providing each candidate with work experience within the sport, leisure and cultural industry whilst also upskilling them with industry specic qualications.Project lead Ewan Lindores told us: ldquoLIVE My Future is the first employability programme of its kind in the Scottish Borders that will bring together sport, leisure and culture."Candidates will have the opportunity to gain invaluable work experience whilst also gaining qualications and boosting their overall confidence."The goal is that we see each candidate either progress into paid employment with Live Borders or another local employer, or gain access to further education.ldquoItrsquos all part of Live Borders strategy to develop a place where young people are healthier, happier and stronger.The first four weeks of training will involve candidates completing a Level  sports leadership course in and around Galashiels.During weeks five and six, candidates will be involved in supporting Live Borders Easter holiday programmes and attending relevant training and development courses.The remaining ten weeks will involve each candidate attending a Live Bordersrsquo work placement that relates to one of the four LIVE My Future pathways on offer ndash Coaching, Operations, Events and Hospitality, and Creative and Connected Communities.The coaching pathway will incorporate work with Active Schools, Sports Development, Play and Health Intervention Promotion. The Operations pathway will involve candidates working within a Live Bordersrsquo facility, supporting the day-to-day running of the facility while also gaining experience of how it is managed.The Events and Hospitality pathway will involve a mix of work with Live Bordersrsquo Events and Programming Officer, helping to plan and deliver small to large-scale events in and around the Scottish Borders, as well as hospitality work within venues such as Heart of Hawick, Harestanes and the Teviotdale Leisure Centre Cafeacute.And the Creative and Connected Communities pathway will involve work within a Live Bordersrsquo archive, library or museum, supporting the day-to-day running and gaining experience of how it is managed.LIVE My Future starts on Monday, March and will run until Friday, June .For the duration of the programme, each candidate will receive pound per week plus travel expenses.Iniduals who are interested in applying must send their CV and submit an application form in writing to Emily Ho, Direct Partners,  Rutland Square, Edinburgh, EH BB or by email to emily@directpartnersApplication forms can be downloaded via the website, www.liveborders.org.uk livemyfuture.The deadline for applications is pm on Friday, February .

title: jazz-comes-to-fountainhall
story: JAZZ festival favourites Ian Millar and Dominic Spencer are heading to Fountainhall next month.Ian and Dominic have been performing together for a number of years playing melodic improvisations on jazz standards and original compositions.Their style of jazz concentrates on developing melodic ideas within the framework of the melody of a tune, whilst maintaining the concept and groove behind it.The result is a very accessible melodic style which allows them to explore, improvise and develop ideas without losing the essence of each piece of music, and to interact together in as creative a way as possible.They have had enormous success over many years during the Edinburgh Fringe Festival with their very successful show ldquoJazz at Lunchtime.Thousands of people have come to see them perform, with many sell-out shows. Anumber of visitors to the Edinburgh Fringe from all over the world have ed year after year.Based in Edinburgh, Scotland, the duo has regularly and extensively toured throughout the UK.They have embarked on many rural tours under their ldquoJazz in the Village series, playing in hundreds of halls, often bringing jazz for the first time to remote communities, performing in intimate settings to appreciative audiences.And the good people of Fountainhall will be able to hear why they are so popular when Ian and Domic pull up at the village hall on Friday, February .Tickets, priced at pound for adults and free for accompanies children, are available from Stow Post Office,

title: gods-kitchen-is-serving-up-a-community-feast-in-selkirk
story: THEY may not be feeding , quite yet but Gods Kitchen in Selkirk is certainly pulling in the punters.Founded last September by Selkirk Baptist Church the Sunday afternoon dining club is proving to be hugely popular.Dozens enjoy the weekly feast and blether, aptly named Gods Kitchen.And even more will be made welcome.Rev Brian Talbot told us: "Its a new kind of church service every Sunday afternoon for folk that have some faith or none."The service consists in sharing a first class home-cooked meal around a table with folk who might find church a little daunting."Between the main course and desert, someone might share some creative writing, someone might bring a guitar and share a song, one of the children might show us a picture theyrsquove just coloured in."We read from the bible."Jesus had a lot to say whilst sharing a meal with ordinary folk in the community."Sometimes what Jesus said, leads us into a good conversation - other times, we go straight for the pudding."Sukie, from Sukiersquos Scones pop-up shop fame, is the main Gods Kitchen chef.And theres rarely a scrap left on the plates by the end of each meal.Selkirk Baptist Church provides the meals for free and theyd like to share their generosity far and wide.The Rev Talbot added: "The outcome is community."We are meeting neighbours of all ages, from all walks of le, becoming friends and sharing burdens in prayer."Itrsquos been goodhellipand we want more folk to come join us."Gods Kitchen takes place every Sunday afternoon from .pm at Connections,  Back Row, Selkirk.

title: parent-power-raises-langlee-classroom-from-the-ashes
story: TEACHERS at a Galashiels primary school has hailed the parent power which has led to a torched outdoor classroom being rebuilt.Pupils, teachers and parents at Langlee Primary were devastated last November when they discovered a woodland hut and surrounding fence had been set alight by vandals.The woodland area adjoining the school was popular with children from pre-school age all the way up to primary seven for outdoor activities.Due to the damage, the whole area had to be cordoned off by staff.And police were brought in to investigate the crime.During December mum Nicola Kelly dipped into her own pocket to buy timber and as she recruited fellow parent Chris Brown to help to raise the outdoor classroom from the ashes.And earlier this month the new hut was officially opened.Langlee teacher Keith Guthrie told us: "The space is a valuable learning resource for the pupils who were very upset when they discovered what had happened and could not access it."Chris did a wonderful job in cold weather and spoke to very inquisitive children about what he was doing."We as a school would like to thank Nicola for organising and paying for all of this and it came as a complete surprise when we found out it was going ahead."We are proud to have such positive people as part of our school community and are delighted they thought of us when it came to this act of kindness and generosity."As well as purchasing most of the materials for the new hut, mum Nicola recruited local joiner Chris to carry out the building work.Mr Brown, who has children at Langlee Primary, volunteered his services and for two days removed the damaged sections before building the new outdoor classroom.Chris told us: "I love working with wood and it has been a pleasure to work on the hut."I enjoyed speaking to the kids and letting them know about how to fix things and how to be safe when using the dferent tools."Local firm Jewsons donated products to treat the finished wood.Mum Nicola is delighted with the new outdoor classroom.She said: "All of my children have used this space from nursery age and have loved using this space to explore the woodland area."Itrsquos a great benefit to the whole school and I just wanted to do something nice."

title: jobseeker-remanded-after-disturbance-at-benefits-office
story: A BORDERS jobseeker has been found guilty after a trial at Jedburgh Sherf Court of causing a disturbance in an unemployment benefit office.Forty five year old Noel Kelly, of Deanhead Drive in Eyemouth, had denied behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in the premises at Upper Houndlaw in Eyemouth on Wednesday, December .After finding him guilty of shouting and swearing and threatening staff, Sherf Derrick McIntytre deferred sentence until February  for the production of background reports.Kelly was remanded in custody until that date.

title: scottish-borders-council-to-be-asked-to-back-second-brexit-vote
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is being asked to back a second vote on Brexit.Opposition leader Stuart Bellhas submitted a motion which would see the council writing to both Holyrood and Westminster in support of either a second referendum or a general election.The motion reads: ldquoAs the UK Parliament has been unable to agree upon terms for withdrawal from the EU and as the facts about, and implications of, withdrawal are now clear, Scottish Borders Council considers that the case for withdrawal should be directly decided by the British people on the basis of the actual facts.ldquoThe council resolves to communicate this opinion to the UK Government and to all local MPs and MSPs.Outlining his reasons for submitting the motion, councillor Bell commented: ldquoThe potential impact on the Borders economy of a chaotic departure from the European Union could be so severe that I think the council cannot sit back and not express an opinion. ldquoI tried to get Scottish Borders Council to wake up to Brexit challenges in March last year, but a motion proposed then was defeated by five votes with those refusing to take action, or refusing even to have an opinion, arguing that it was premature. ldquoI donrsquot think that argument will carry weight now, with just two months to go before we leave Europe. The council needs to take a lead and speak up.ldquoIt is now clear, and indeed it is alarming, that the UK Parliament is blocked and has been unable to make a clear decision on which route to take and on how Brexit should be brought to pass.ldquoThe clock is ticking down to a departure from Europe and just last week the confederation of British industry stated that under some scenarios there could be lsquodisastrousrsquo implications for Scottish productivity and economic prospects. ldquoWhilst that is only some scenarios, it is unacceptable to me that the UK Parliament cannot decide what to do. ldquoThe decision should be put back to the people, precisely because Parliament is now blocked. That could be through a general election or it could be through another EU referendum.ldquoI maintain that to now have a referendum, based on definite proposals and on an honest statement of the facts about leaving Europe would not betray the decision taken in . ldquoThe real options were not clear two years ago, but now we have some facts. Anyway, people who are confident of their arguments donrsquot run away from a referendum.ldquoBut maybe the people should decide through a general election. Either way the UK Parliament is failing on this and now the people, themselves, must decide.The council meets on Thursday, January , where elected members will be asked to vote on councillor Bellrsquos motion.

title: council-could-help-with-food-crackdown
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council officers could take on a larger role policing the selling and marketing of high fat, high sugar and high salt foods.In a paper which is set to go before councillors on Thursday, council officers have outlined a draft response to a Scottish Government consultation on reducing health problems associated with calorie intake.In the paper, council officers suggest that as the councilrsquos trading standards team already has experience around alcohol and tobacco restrictions, then it would lsquomake sense to utilise that expertisersquo.The draft response on enforcement, whichapproved will be sent to the Scottish Government, reads: ldquoLocal authorities have experience of similar enforcement regimes in relation to tobacco and nicotine vapour products and have had a role in the online pricing of alcohol following the implementation of the minimum pricing legislation.ldquoWhilst it would be for the local authority to determine which service is best placed to enforce the proposals, trading standards already have a role in policing pricing and it would make sense to utilise the expertise that already exists in the local authority.ldquoHowever, it should be recognised that there will be a need for Scottish Government to work with local authorities to quanty current and future resources required to police pricing promotions and to provide these to local authorities to reduce the inevitable additional burden that the proposed restrictions will create.In July  the Scottish Government produced a paper which set out the foods it felt needed to be targeted in order to reduce the caloric intake and weight of Scottish people.These include: confectionery sweet biscuits crisps savoury snacks cakes pastries puddings and soft drinks with added sugar.The consultation askslocal authorities agree with this list, and whether more items should be added.In their draft consultation response, Scottish Borders Council officers believe that ice-cream, ready meals and dairy desserts should also be included in the crackdown: ldquoWhile it will certainly be useful to target the discretionary foods listed above there is also a need to include drinks high in sugar, salt, fat or calories irrespective of whether or not this is lsquoaddedrsquo.ldquoSimilarly ice-cream and dairy desserts should also come under the scope of the new policy as they are often high in fat and high in sugar and do not form an essential dietary component.ldquoWhile diary-based desserts could offer some benefits in terms of calcium and other nutrients, these would be available from other sources in a healthy diet.ldquoTheir benefit in a dairy-based dessert would be offset by the high energy density and presence of salts, sugars and fats.According to the NHS Health Scotland, in ,  per cent of Scotlandrsquos children were at risk of becoming overweight, and  per cent were at risk of becoming obese. In ,  per cent of adults were overweight including  per cent obese.The NHS says that some of the health risks of being overweight include an increase chance of developing type  diabetes, heart disease, stroke, and some cancers.

title: 83-year-old-dick-drives-into-the-guinness-book-of-world-records
story: AN -year-old lorry driver from Ashkirk has just parked up on the pages of the Guinness Book of World Records.Dick Henderson has spent almost five decades behind the wheel for several local haulage firms.And on Saturday he was presented with the official Guinness Book of Records certicate during a surprise party.Dick, who was  years and  days old when he was officially certied as the oldest, beats the previous record which was held for  years by -year-old Robert Currie.Dick told us: "I never knew a thing about the record - it was all a big surprise when I went down for a pint on Saturday."I began driving when I was  on the Co-op coal lorry and thats what Ive been doing ever since."Ive no intention of stopping -I feel I cant do it any more Ill stop, but I dont see that happening for a while yet."Working le for Dick began on a farm just after the Second World War.In  he got his first taste of driving with the Cooperative coal lorry then for a lime delivery firm in Hawick.After a spell at Philiphaugh Estate in Selkirk, Dick worked for several local companies including Thomas Mitchell of Ettrickbridge.He did retire from Baxters of Pathead at the start of the millennium - for just TWO days.And he quickly got back in the driving seat with his sons firm, Elliot Hendersons, in Selkirk.Dick, who was widowed in the s, added: "Retirement wasnt for me."I was bored after two days and went back to work."On Saturday Dick was joined by sons Elliot and Roderick, and daughter Lesley, along with his grandchildren and great-grandchildren to celebrate his inclusion in the Guinness Book of World Records at The Smiddy in his home village.Former colleagues from Baxters also joined in the celebrations.Grandson Gavin, who works with his grandfather in Selkirk, organised the surprise party.He said: "We first contacted the Guinness World Records almost a year ago and its been a y process where they have to validate all of the paperwork to prove my granddad is the oldest."Hes remarkable for his age and I cant imagine his record will be beaten any time soon"

title: galas-ali-balie-bee-sweetseller-to-be-cast-in-bronze
story: THE search is on to put a face to the Galashiels man who penned the world-famous lullaby Ali Bali Bee.A statue to Coulters Candy originator Robert Coltart will be unveiled in his hometown this summer.But the people behind the le-sized bronze tribute are desperately trying to confirman old newspaper photograph sent from Canada is the weaver-turned-sweet seller.Historians Graeme McIver and Mary Craig have been championing Coltarts story for over a decade.And they are delighted that celebrated sculptor Angela Hunter is currently sketching designs for the tribute which will be placed in the towns Market Place.Graeme told us: "Coulterrsquos Candy is arguably Scotlandrsquos best known and most loved childrenrsquos song and it is fantastic that at long last there will be a permanent reminder."To coin a phrase we used during our research, lsquoAli Bali is actually from Guid Auld Galaersquo."The town has faced challenges in attracting new visitors and this statue, along with the other proposed regeneration works, will Irsquom sure provide a much needed boost for Galashiels.ldquoAngela Hunterrsquos work is fantastic and it has been a pleasure looking at her ideas for how the finished statue will look."I am sure it will become a much loved local attraction and will rekindle interest in the story of Robert Coltart and the song.Robert Coltart was born in Dumfries and Galloway and moved to Galashiels at a young age, like many at the time, to work in the mills.It was during the s that is thought he began making aniseed-flavoured toffee at his Overhaugh Street home.As well as doing a fine trade at fairs, he would sell his candy around the streets of his adopted hometown playing a whistle and singing his jingle - Ali Balie Bee - with a trail of children in his wake.Coltart also lived at houses in Henderson Close and Park Street, which have both since been demolished.And he was known to travel to nearby Melrose and Selkirk, as well as other Borders towns, to sell his candy on the streets - traders in Selkirk even raised a court order against him as he was taking away their trade.One report from the time states: "He wore a tam a shanter, or was it a Balmoral bonnet  With a pheasantrsquos feather sticking straight up from a buckle above his ear."A shiny black bag slung over his shoulder held stock of the famous candy!"While there are many descriptions of the larger-than-le Robert Coltart, who died in  at the age of , only one photograph is known to exist.And the researches, as well as sculptor Angela, are trying to have the image veried before the final detail is made to the bronze statue.Angela, whose work includes the iconic Turn bull bronze in Hawick, said: "We do have one newspaper cutting from the Gala Post, sent from Canada, and we are hoping to confirm this is Robert.ldquoIt is hoped that someone may have further information on his le, so we can make this sculpture as accurate as possible."I was born in Galashiels and am therefore incredibly proud to be involved in this project."Although the recipe for Coulters Candy was lost after Roberts death, his Ali Balie Bee jingle was passed through the generations.And after it began to be sung at folk nights all over the country in the s, eventually being recorded by Donovan in .The statue, which will feature Coltart selling his candy with two children by his side, will be erected close to his Overhaugh Street home at Market Square.The artwork is part of a new town trail, supported by the Scottish Governmentrsquos Regeneration Capital Grant Fund.The fund provided a pound.m grant last year, a proportion of which is being used to fund pound, of streetscape improvements.Among the supporters of the statue and trail is business councillor Mark Rowley.Councillor Rowley said: ldquoThe story of Robert Coltart is a fascinating one which should be known by more people and alongside the other regeneration works taking place in Galashiels, I am sure it will attract people to the town and the Borders.ldquoA partnership approach is being used to take forward the project with a iety of stakeholders from the local community and businesses involved in finalising the streetscape improvements as priorities."These improvement works would not have been possible without the Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor complex, which helped secure the overall support from the Scottish Government Regeneration Grant Fund.ldquoThis year is to be an exciting one as Galashiels is re-shaped and investment encouraged in the town and the wider Borders economy as part of the Galashiels Masterplan.Helen Calder of Energise Galashiels Trust has also championed Coltartrsquos story.She added: ldquoWe are delighted to play our part in the telling of the story of Robert Coltart."Ali Bali is such a world-famous nursery rhyme that we see real opportunity in celebrating its link to our town.Robert Coltart was buried in an unmarked paupers grave at Eastland Cemetery.But his legacy willto his hometown in June with the unveiling of the bronze in Market Square.Anyone with further information or images of Coltart can contact Angela on angie@angelahunter.

title: pm-ready-to-reopen-eu-negotiations-in-bid-to-win-mps-support
story: Theresa May has told Cabinet she is ready to reopen Brexit negotiations with the EU to secure changes to the controversial backstop plan to avoid a hard border in Ireland.The Prime Minister said that, following this monthrsquos crushing -vote defeat in the Commons, it was clear that only reopening the Withdrawal Agreement and changing the backstop will win MPsrsquo support for her EU deal.In a change to previously announced plans, she was addressing MPs at the start of debate on a series of proposed amendments to the deal, urging them to back proposals from Tory grandee Sir Graham Brady to replace the backstop with ldquoalternative arrangements.In an apparent attempt to fend off possible defeat on other amendments which could delay Brexit or rule out a no-deal departure, Mrs May promised that Tuesdayrsquos votes would not be MPsrsquo final chance to pass judgment on EU withdrawal.Her hopes of a majority for the Brady amendment were boosted when former foreign secretary and Brexit figurehead Boris Johnson said he would ldquogladly vote for it ndashit meant the Withdrawal Agreement being reopened and legally binding changes being made to the backstop.We canrsquot have some codicil or letter or joint declaration. We need to go back into the text of the treaty and solve the problem. That is the way to unite remainers and leavers in the Conservative party and across the country  mdash Boris JohnsonJanuary , But the chances of the Commons derailing her plans were also heightened when Labour confirmed it will back a cross-party bid to push Brexit day back from March  to as late as the end of this year and put Parliament in the driving seat on the way forward.This proposal, tabled by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper and Tory Nick Boles, is one of the strongest-backed of a bevy of rival amendments tabled for debate. Only those selected by Speaker John Bercow will go forward to a vote.Mrs May is expected to have phone discussions with key EU leaders over the course of the day, with votes taking place in the early evening.Speaking to Cabinet, she said she aims toto the Commons ldquoas soon as possible with a revised deal, which will be subject to a ldquomeaningful vote of MPs. If it is defeated, she will table another amendable motion for debate the following day.If no new deal is reached by February , the PM will make a statement to Parliament that day and table an amendable motion for debate the following day.Her announcement brought the prospect of the cancellation of Parliamentrsquos half-term recess a step closer, as the Commons is currently due to rise for its -day break on February .Brussels has been adamant that it will not reopen the Agreement, struck by Mrs May and European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker and signed off by leaders of the remaining  EU states last November.European Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas said the EU was waiting to see what happened in Parliament.ldquoThis is not a Brussels day, this is a London day. We have the vote tonight and then we will take it from there, he said.And Irelandrsquos European Affairs Minister, Helen McEntee, cautioned: ldquoThere can be no change to the backstop. It was negotiated over  months with the UK and by the UK. A bit of realism is needed at this stage.But Mrs Mayrsquos official spokesman said: ldquoThere is a very clear message from the EUrsquos leaders that they want the UK to leave with a deal and that they understand this is in the best interests of the EU as well as the UK.Mrs May told Cabinet that a majority for the Brady amendment would send three vital messages to the EU by:ndash Making clear that the will of the House of Commons is to leave with a dealndash Setting out in no uncertain terms that the UK continues to be committed to arrangements which avoid a hard border in Ireland andndash Creating scope for new discussions with the EU on how best to achieve that.ldquoThe Prime Minister said that in order to win the support of the House of Commons, legal changes to the backstop will be required, said Mrs Mayrsquos spokesman. ldquoThat will mean reopening the Withdrawal Agreement.Tory MPs were told at a meeting with Mrs May on Monday evening that they would be whipped to support the Brady amendment.Butit was far from clear whether this instruction would be followed by enough of the  Conservatives who rebelled against Mrs Mayrsquos deal on January .MPs rejected Theresa Mayrsquos EU withdrawal deal by a record margin of  votes earlier this month The leader of the European Research Groupof eurosceptic backbenchers, Jacob Rees-Mogg, initially said its members were not prepared to support the Brady plan, though he later appeared to soften his line.Remain-backing Tories may rally behind the Cooper Boles amendment, while other proposals may gain cross-party support, including a plan by Conservative Caroline Spelman and Labourrsquos Jack Dromey to rule out a no-deal Brexit.Meanwhile, a compromise drafted by Conservative MPs from both the Remain and Leave sides of the party won the crucial backing of the Democratic Unionist Party.Drawn up in meetings co-ordinated by housing minister Kit Malthouse, thecompromise recasts thebackstop as a ldquofree trade agreement-lite, with a commitment on all sides there should be no hard border and an extended transition period to December .DUP leader Arlene Foster ndash whose  MPs prop up the minority Conservative administration in the Commons ndash said it provided a ldquofeasible alternative to the backstop.ldquoIf the Prime Minister is seeking to find a united front, both between elements in her own party and the DUP, in the negotiations which she will enter with the European Union, then this is a proposition which she should not turn her back on, said Mrs Foster.Former minister Nicky Morgan has been involved in talks on the so-called lsquoMalthouse compromisersquo Mrs Mayrsquos spokesman said the PM ldquowelcomes the fact that MPs are working together to come up with solutions, but declined to pass judgment on the Malthouse compromise.Remain-backing former minister Nicky Morgan said discussions had been taking place for ldquosome days between herself, health minister Stephen Hammond and Solicitor General Robert Buckland on one side and Mr Rees-Mogg and Steve Baker from the ERG on the other.ldquoThe Prime Minister has been aware of the discussions. At some point there has to be compromise on all sides in order to get a deal over the line. That is what most of us want to see ndash a negotiated settlement with the EU, she said..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: PM ready to reopen EU negotiations in bid to win MPs u support

story: I have always been proud to be a Campbeltonian, but never more so than in the dficult weeks following the disastrous fire at Machrihanish Golf Club.In our family, we have experienced what Robert Burns described as: #The naked truth, the real guid and ill.#The naked truth is that no lives were lost.  We are still part of a loving and very supportive family.Each one of us has many good and helpful friends, and we are part of this wonderful community in Campbeltown and Kintyre and also throughout the country and the wider world.Thank you, all of you, for you are holding us up.Agnes R Stewart,Campbeltown.

title: focus on young nature filmmakers
story: The Scottish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animalshas launched its first ever primary and secondary school film competition for schools.Scotland’s animal welfare charity visits schools every year to deliverits free Prevention through Education programme, encouraging pupils to become responsible animal citizens.The programme links in with many areas of the Curriculum for Excellence and aims to encourage empathy and compassion towards animals.Primary and secondary schools have been invited to submit a short film that educates the public, and in particular their peers, on key animal welfare issues that the Scottish SPCA regularly have to tackle.The competition gives schools the opportunity to engage their students in a creative and cross curricular activity with the opportunity to win prizes for both themselves and the school.The judging  will be looking for innovative and creative methods of conveying a key message to the public, in particular to other school students.Scottish SPCA#s head of education and policy, Gilly Mendes Ferreira said: #Since  we have seen a more than  per cent increase in the number of calls where children have alerted us to animals in need of our help, which saved injured wildle and uncovered cases of neglect.#We are thrilled to be launching this competition for both primary and secondary schools and hope that this continues to encourage children and young adults to be #AlwaysAnimalAware.#We truly believe children are the key to making a real dference to animal welfare in Scotland.#The topics, consent forms, terms and conditions, closing date for submissions and more information  can be found on the Scottish SPCA website at scottishspca.org education The winning films will be announced in June .

story: Later reflecting on cellist Jamal Aliyev and pianist Jâms Coleman#s visit memories resurfaced of school days.Despite many of us being quite unmusical, trips were organised to listen to the greats of the day, both popular and classical.Monday#s senior Kintyre Music Club audience was treated to a virtuoso display.Kintyre is noted for its musicianship but pupils, who can attend the club#s concerts free, were noticeably absent.It was a school night, however the same is largely true of the club#s Friday night concerts.There was much advance publicity including a picture of young Jamal hugging his cello like a rockstar.The pair are playing parish and church halls on their Scottish tour but, next month, Jamal will play a two night show, as a soloist, with the Presidential Symphony Orchestra in Ankara, Turkey.On page three there is much about the Grammar School#s progress, watching Jamal and Jâms perform was equally an education.It was dferent when the BBC SSO visited it took the show to schools.

title: down memory lane january 18 2018
story: A current Kintyre publication is packed with more than a dozen fascinating stories many of which would make good entries in Down Memory Lane.The latest issue of The Kintyre Magazine, edited by Angus Martin, opens with an eight-and-a-half page feature on the history of explorations into Beinn Ghuilean#s Piper#s Cave, by the editor.Mr Martin has uncovered some gems from the Courier archive, including finding possible prehistoric animal bones, in the cave, which he states was in an over dramatised report # surely not.#The Road Surfacemen# by Murdo MacDonald is particularly aposite given the huge number of potholes afflicting Kintyre roads.When the first motor car arrived in Campbeltown finding any surface may have been a problem. The tale is recounted in #Early Motoring in Campbeltown# by Angus Martin.Elizabeth Marrison has investigated a ledger for a Muasdale shop dating from  to  in: #A Rural Shop in th Century Kintyre.#Items purchased include a black silk hankerchief, half-a-pound of Spanish indigo, and a roll of lbs twist tobacco.Methods of payment include nine carts of peet, for often bills were settled in kind.Peter McIntosh delves into Irish history in: #The  Rebellion and the Saddell Volunteers.##A Case of Mutiny: The Strange Story of the Arriero,# by Ian Wilson begins with a quote from Dr Johnson who said: #That being on a ship is like being in jail with the chance of drowning.#The signicance of that quotation is discovered on learning about the five mutineers# appearance in front of Sherf Gardiner.Genetics and genealogy is the subject of Jerry Loynachan#s #Loynachan Family Y-DNA.#Even non-Loynachan family will find interest in his explanation of the Y-chromosome in tracing male genetic roots.Angus Martin#s regular item #By Hill and Shore,# a diary of trips from February to August, last year, picks out his main subjects such as PRIMROSE, HERRING GULL AND OTTER in block capitals making them easy to spot in the text.A Courier #From our Files# tale of an adder bite, from last August, has prompted Sandy McMillan to write about his own meeting with Britain#s only venomous snake in: #An Encounter with an Adder.#In advance of the Kintyre Antiquarians talk, by Ronald Togneri, featured in last week#s Courier, Mr Martin, in #Two Archibald MacKinnon Paintings# tells the tale, from the Courier#s discovery, through to purchase, by the friends of Campbeltown Museum, of a pair of artworks.It is not all praise though, and the Courier#s July  report, of the purchase, is corrected for stating that MacKinnon taught at the Grammar School, which he did not.The Kintyre Magazine front cover featuring photographer Nellie Barnes. The publication is available from The Old Bookshelf in Cross Street. NO_ckintyremag_issue

title: from our files january 18 2019
story: Friday January  Natasha reaches regional finalsGrammar School pupil Natasha Lee emerged as winner of the Argyll and Bute heat of the Future Chef competition when she travelled to Rothesay last month.The S pupil#s menu was a pork mushroom medley with Panchetta and black pudding pilaf which was served with roasted tomatoes in garlic oil.This was followed by berry and lemon Mille Feuille served with an almond-infused quenelle of cream.Since she was very young Natasha has wanted to become a chef and enjoys home economics at school.She is planning to study hospitality and work as a chef in a restaurant, making her success in the Future Chef competition an impressive first step towards her future career.Natasha went forward to the Scottish regional final at the Thistle Hotel, Inverness on January  andshe is successful she will be off to London for the UK final. title: anonymous tip off leads to ban
story: On October  last year, as Nichola McFall drove away from a Burnside Square bar, police received an anonymous call alerting them that she had been drinking.Procurator fiscal depute Eoin McGinty told Campbeltown Sherf Court that, McFall, , of  Duntocher Road, Parkhall, had pulled into the forecourt of the County garage, where her car was later found, but told there was no toilet.When police found her at Co-op, across the road, she had been abusive to staff and was arguing with a member of the public.McFall failed the roadside breath test and was taken to Campbeltown police station.She called the police f****** liars and demanded that her community psychiatric nurse be contacted. Following this McFall was taken to hospital.At last Thursday’s hearing McFall pleaded guilty to two charges – one of being . times over the drink-drive limit and another of threatening behaviour at Co-op.McFall’s defence solicitor said she had little recollection of the incident, perhaps due to her anti-psychotic medication and drink being a bad combination.Sherf Patrick Hughes disqualied McFall for  months.The disqualication would be reduced by a quartershe took a drink driver’s rehabilitation course and he fined her a total of £ to be paid at £ per month.

title: letter wild salmon migration
story: It was recently reported that the Scottish Gamekeepers Associationis calling for a ban on fish farms being built on wild salmon migration routes.The SGA fishing group believe careful positioning of proposed farms and re-siting problem pens could stop wild stocks being infested with parasites‎.Crown Estate Scotland, under the Freedom of InformationAct ‎, confirmed MOWI, formerly known as Marine Harvest, has a lease option agreement to a third site in the Kilbrannan Sound.This is a short term conditional agreement, for a secure and exclusive interest, that can be exercised for a full lease once all necessary consents # including planning permission and the marine licence have been secured.With the planned expansion, by an increase of  per cent, of the two existing MOWI sites, at Carradale and a third site at Cour Point, Kilbrannan Sound will be home to the single largest concentration of fish farm pens and salmon biomass in Europe.The SGA believe sea lice outbreaks from salmon farms contribute to the collapse of wild salmon stocks.A spokesperson said: #While a healthy salmon can survive with a burden of sealice, the high number of lice found in captive areas can lead to weakness and death.#Does Argyll and Bute Council and the Scottish Government acknowledge both the impact of sea lice and the subsequent use of chemicals, presently being felt in the Kilbrannan Sound An impact not only on wild salmon and sea trout stocks also our very localised lobster, crab and prawn fishing industry In past decades Kilbrannan Sound would have been described as a super highway for migrating wild salmon.Legislation in Norway, and recently British Colombia, does not permit the siting of fish farms on recognised wild salmon migration routes.Is it the local authority and national government#s intention to down grade the Sound, once plentul in fish and crustaceans alike, to that of a backwater trickle Tommy Macpherson,Saddell.
